201 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Clark v. Craven Regional Medical Authority


No. 343PA89


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


326 N.C. 15; 387 S.E.2d 168; 1990 N.C. LEXIS 9


November 16, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
January 18, 1990, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On plaintiffs' petition pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31(b) for discretionary review prior to determination by the Court of Appeals of an order by Strickland, J. dismissing plaintiffs' action and enjoining plaintiffs from enforcing stop work orders against the defendants. Order entered on 15 June 1989, nunc pro tunc for 15 May 1989, in Superior Court, Craven County.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sought review of the order North Carolina Court of Appeals granting a plea of abatement to defendant medical authority in their action to obtain requisite building permits from and payment of appropriate fees.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs brought an action against defendant medical authority seeking to obtain requisite building permits and payment of appropriate fees. Plaintiffs appealed the decision granting a plea in abatement in the matter. On appeal, the court affirmed the trial court decision granting a plea in abatement. The court held that the parties, the subject matter, the issues involved, and the relief requested were sufficiently similar to warrant issuance of the order of abatement in this case. The court held that the purpose of abatement by reason of the pendency of the prior action is whether the two actions present a substantial identity as to parties, subject matter, issues involved, and relief demanded. The court found the test to have been met in the present case.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that granted a plea in abatement.

 

202 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Madison Cablevision, Inc. v. Morganton


No. 624PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


325 N.C. 634; 386 S.E.2d 200; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 598; 1990-1 Trade Cas. (CCH) P68,933


May 11, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
December 7, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 prior to a determination by the Court of Appeals of a judgment entered on 6 July 1987 by Gaines, J., in the Superior Court, Burke County, granting summary judgment for the defendant, City of Morganton.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff sought review of the decision of the Superior Court, Burke County (North Carolina), upon certification of state constitutional questions from a federal district court, granting defendant city's right to establish a public cable television service.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff provided cable television access in defendant city for 20 years. When plaintiff's franchise expired, defendant held public hearings and decided to provide cable television services itself, rather than award the franchise to a privately-owned bidder. Plaintiff sued in federal court, challenging defendant's ability to own and operate a cable television system. The federal court held that the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, 47 U.S.C.S. § 546, was inapplicable to the facts but abstained from deciding state constitutional issues, which were certified to the state's highest court, which held in favor of defendant city. N.C. Const. art. V, § 2(1) authorized the state legislature to pass statutes defining "public enterprise" to include cable television systems and to grant cities the authority to own and operate them. The court broadly construed the term "public purpose" to include services offered in direct competition with those provided by privately-owned corporations.


OUTCOME: The state's highest court affirmed, holding that municipal operation of a cable television service was authorized by the state constitution and statutes because it fell within the definition of a "public purpose."

 

203 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Martin v. Preston


No. 58PA89


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


325 N.C. 438; 385 S.E.2d 473; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 539


October 11, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
November 9, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review prior to a determination by the Court of Appeals, pursuant to Rule 15(a) of the North Carolina Rules of Appellate Procedure and N.C.G.S. § 7A-31(a), of judgment entered by McKinnon, J., in Superior Court, Wake County, on 17 November 1988.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff governor and defendants, judges, elections board, and lawyers association, appealed the judgment of the Superior Court of Wake County (North Carolina), which granted in part and denied in part the parties' respective motions for summary judgment in the governor's action challenging the constitutionality of 1987 N.C. Sess. Laws ch. 509. The parties' petition for discretionary review, prior to the court of appeals' decision, was allowed.


OVERVIEW: The governor sought a declaration that certain provisions of Chapter 509 violated the state constitution. The provisions challenged increased the number of superior court judicial districts, changed the election dates for nine judgeships to eliminate staggered terms, and imposed residency requirements. The trial court held that, to the extent that Chapter 509 extended the terms of some judgeships and designated the incumbent judge to hold over, it was unconstitutional. Summary judgment was granted for the governor on this issue. As to all other provisions, summary judgment was granted for defendants. Appeal followed, and the court reversed the judgment in part and affirmed it in part. The state constitution did not specify when judicial elections were to be held, but it did have a holdover provision. Thus, the creation of a one-time delay of elections and a one-time interim, between terms, was constitutional. Because the incumbent judges were assigned to subdivisions of the former district for which they were elected, the residency requirement was maintained. The pre-candidacy residency requirement did not unconstitutionally deny qualified candidates the right to seek office.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment insofar as it held that the one-time delay of elections and one-time hiatus, between terms, violated the state constitution. Thus, the injunctive relief granted by the trial court was dissolved. The court, however, affirmed the remaining parts of the trial court's judgment which declared that the other provisions of the challenged legislation did not violate the state constitution.

 

204 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Finch v. Durham


No. 85PA89


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


325 N.C. 352; 384 S.E.2d 8; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 483


May 9, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 5, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review prior to determination by the Court of Appeals pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31(a) and Rule 15(e)(2) of the Rules of Appellate Procedure of a judgment upon (1) a jury verdict that a taking had occurred; (2) a judicial determination that the taking was not arbitrary or capricious; and (3) an alternative judicial determination that a taking had occurred, which invalidated one city ordinance and waived another, awarded damages and granted attorney's fees and costs to plaintiffs, entered by Bowen, J., at the 14 March 1987 Civil Session of Superior Court, Durham County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a judgment of the Superior Court of Durham County (North Carolina) awarding damages to appellee landowners in an action brought by the landowners, challenging one of the city's zoning ordinances.


OVERVIEW: Landowners owned land within a city. After the city changed its zoning ordinances with respect to the land, the landowners brought an action against the city. The trial court entered a judgment in favor of the landowners, but did not award damages. The landowners filed a motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict, and the trial court granted the motion and awarded damages. The city sought review, and the court reversed. The court held that the changing of the zoning ordinance was not a taking, because the land maintained a practical use and a reasonable value. Also, the zoning ordinance had a substantial relation to public health and welfare. Finally, there was no guarantee to the landowners that the ordinance would not be changed. The trial court should have granted the city's motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment in favor of the landowners.

 

205 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Artis


No. 504A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


325 N.C. 278; 384 S.E.2d 470; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 482


May 10, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 5, 1989, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Vacated by Artis v. North Carolina, 494 U.S. 1023, 110 S. Ct. 1466, 108 L. Ed. 2d 604, 1990 U.S. LEXIS 1467 (1990)


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgment sentencing him to death for conviction of murder in the first degree, said judgment imposed by Pope, J., at the 20 August 1984 session of Superior Court, Robeson County.
State v. Artis, 313 N.C. 502, 329 S.E.2d 405, 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1692 (1985)



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from the judgment of the Superior Court, Robeson County (North Carolina), which upon a jury verdict convicted him of murder in the first degree and sentenced him to death.


OVERVIEW: Evidence indicated that the victim had been killed by manual strangulation during involuntary sexual intercourse. The court rejected defendant's numerous points of error with regard to both the guilt and penalty phases of his trial. The remoteness of an incident testified to regarding an attempted rape and manual strangulation which had occurred more that ten years previous was outweighed by the relevancy provided by the similarities to the incident for which defendant was on trial. Moreover, defendant failed to object at trial, and because he did not show a reasonable possibility that had the testimony been excluded, a different result would have been reached at his trial, he could not have met the even heavier burden imposed by the test for plain error. The particular circumstances of the crime, including having struck the victim with a large stick several times in the head, forcing her to disrobe, forcing intercourse with her while she was semi-conscious, strangling her in the midst of sexual intercourse, hiding the body, and going home to sleep rather than seeking medical attention for the victim were sufficient for the jury to find defendant guilty of first degree murder.


OUTCOME: Defendant's conviction of murder in the first degree and sentence of death were affirmed.

 

206 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Huff


No. 372A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


325 N.C. 1; 381 S.E.2d 635; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 369


December 13, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 26, 1989, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected October 31, 1989.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from convictions and judgments entered thereon imposing a sentence of death for the murder in the first degree of Crigger Huff and a sentence of life imprisonment for the murder in the first degree of Gail Strickland, entered by Brewer, J., at the 8 June 1987 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Cumberland County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the judgment of the Criminal Session of Superior Court, Cumberland County (North Carolina), which imposed a sentence of death for the murder in the first degree of his infant son and a sentence of life imprisonment for the murder in the first degree of his mother-in-law.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of two counts of first-degree murder, both of them upon the theory of premeditation and deliberation. Conviction on the first count was for the murder of defendant's infant son and conviction on the second count was for the murder of defendant's mother-in-law. Upon the jury's recommendation, the trial court sentenced defendant to death for the murder of the infant and to life imprisonment for the murder of his mother-in-law. Defendant appealed his conviction, claiming numerous errors. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court. The court held that defendant received a fair trial and sentencing proceeding, free from prejudicial error. The sentence of death was not imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor. Additionally, defendant's death sentence was not disproportionate to the penalty imposed in similar cases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, which imposed a sentence of death for the murder in the first degree of his infant son and a sentence of life imprisonment for the murder in the first degree of his mother-in-law. Defendant received a fair trial and sentencing proceeding, free from prejudicial error and the sentence of death was not imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor.

 

207 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Laws


No. 653A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


325 N.C. 81; 381 S.E.2d 609; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 377


May 9, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 26, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right by the defendant from two judgments sentencing him to death for two convictions of first-degree murder, entered by Cornelius, J., in the Superior Court, Davidson County, on 20 August 1985.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the judgment of the Special Criminal Session of Superior Court, Davidson County (North Carolina), which after a jury trial, convicted him of two counts of first degree murder. Upon the jury's recommendation, the trial court sentenced defendant to death.


OVERVIEW: In challenging the judgment convicting him of two counts of first-degree murder and imposing the death sentence thereon, defendant alleged over 30 errors. The court affirmed and found that the trial court did not abuse its discretion with respect to limits that it placed upon questioning of the prospective jurors during voir dire. In doing so, it noted that counsel did not have the right to inquire into all aspect of the panel's religious beliefs. The court also rejected defendant's claim that there was prosecutorial error throughout the trial which required reversal, noting that the actions of the prosecutor were either within legal limits, or that they did not reach the level of gross impropriety required for reversal. The court found that defendant failed to meet the required test with respect to his claim that his trial counsel was ineffective. The court also found that the trial court properly instructed the jury on mitigating and aggravating circumstances, that the jury's finding with respect to each was supported by the evidence, that the death sentence was not disproportionate or the result of passion on the jury's part.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions for first-degree murder and the imposition of the death penalty.

 

208 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Beech Mountain v. County of Watauga


No. 409A88


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


324 N.C. 409; 378 S.E.2d 780; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 255


February 14, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 4, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by plaintiffs pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(1) from a decision of the Court of Appeals, 91 N.C. App. 87, 370 S.E. 2d 453 (1988), affirming order granting defendants' motion to dismiss by Lamm, J., at the 7 December 1987 session of Superior Court, Watauga County.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, property owners, sought review from a decision of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed an order granting defendant county's motion to dismiss the property owners' constitutional challenges to the per capita distribution under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 105-472 of the county's sales and use tax revenues.


OVERVIEW: The property owners claimed that the per capita method resulted in a 93 percent decrease in sales tax revenues, which forced the municipality to raise taxes and reduce services. They first argued that the method denied them equal protection by creating an arbitrary distinction between those who resided in the county more than six months of the year and those who resided primarily elsewhere. The court disagreed, and found that individuals owning second homes in resort areas were not a downtrodden minority or a suspect class. Nor did the increase in taxes and reduction in services discourage citizens of other counties from purchasing property in the town, thereby violating their right to travel, because property owners, resident and nonresident alike, were equally affected. The court concluded that the statute neither operated to the disadvantage of a suspect class nor interfered with the exercise of a fundamental right, and declined to apply strict scrutiny. The court further concluded that the method was rationally related to a legitimate state interest in that it provided a reasonable means of returning revenues in an amount proportionate to those from whom they were collected.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals dismissing the property owners' challenge to the county's per capita distribution of tax revenues.

 

209 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


In re Appeal from Civil Penalty Assessed for Violations of Sedimentation Pollution Control Act etc.


No. 543A88


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


324 N.C. 373; 379 S.E.2d 30; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 246


February 13, 1989, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 4, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(a) and (b) by the North Carolina Department of Natural Resources and Community Development from the decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, reported at 92 N.C. App. 1, 373 S.E. 2d 572 (1988), affirming the judgment vacating a civil penalty entered by Smith, J., at the 10 February 1987 Session of Superior Court, Wake County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The North Carolina Court of Appeals affirmed a judgment vacating a civil penalty against appellee land developers for violations of the Sedimentation Pollution Control Act of 1973, N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 113A-50 to -66. The North Carolina Department of Natural Resources and Community Development (NRCD) appealed.


OVERVIEW: The land developers disturbed land by grading, cutting and filling, in order to construct a street to provide access to residential lots while developing a subdivision. They had been assessed civil penalties by NRCD for prior violations. The court of appeals concluded that the Act constituted a legislative grant of judicial power prohibited by N.C. Const. art. IV, § 3 did not permit an administrative agency to assess a civil penalty whose amount varied with any agency discretion. The court held that N.C. Const. art. IV, § 3 contemplated that discretionary judicial authority could be granted to an agency when reasonably necessary to accomplish the agency's purposes. The legislature was thus not prohibited from conferring the power on administrative agencies to assess civil penalties, or to exercise discretion in determining civil penalties within an authorized range. The court also determined a panel of the court of appeals was bound by a prior decision of another panel of the same court on the same issue. The court concluded that the civil penalty power was reasonably necessary to the purposes for which NRCD was established.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision vacating the civil penalty of the NRCD.

 

210 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. McNeil


No. 37A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


324 N.C. 33; 375 S.E.2d 909; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 17


May 9, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Additional Arguments Heard  
February 9, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgments imposing death sentences entered by Brewer, Jr., J., at the 30 April 1984 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wake County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed, pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a), from the judgments of the Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina), which convicted defendant of two counts of first degree murder and sentenced him to death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant killed two women in an effort to acquire money to pay his rent. He was convicted of two counts of first degree murder on the basis of premeditation and deliberation and under the felony murder rule. Upon the jury's recommendation, the trial court sentenced defendant to death in both cases. On appeal, the court affirmed and held, inter alia, that: (1) the trial court did not abuse its discretion in consolidating the two cases for trial; (2) the trial court did not err in denying defendant's motion to dismiss; (3) the trial court did not err in removing three jurors for cause because of their feelings about the death penalty; (4) the prosecutor's arguments were not so grossly improper as to require the court to intervene; and (5) the sentencing phase of defendant's trial was fair and free of prejudicial error. The court's proportionality review found that the record supported the jury's findings of aggravating circumstances, the death sentences were not imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor, and the death penalty recommendations were neither excessive nor disproportionate to the penalties imposed in similar cases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed both defendant's convictions for first degree murder and his death sentences.

 

211 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Parks


No. 154A88


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


324 N.C. 94; 376 S.E.2d 4; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 20


October 13, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
February 9, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgments sentencing him to two life sentences upon his convictions of first degree murder and first degree burglary. Judgments imposed by John, J., at the 30 November 1987 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Moore County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his convictions from the Moore County Superior Court (North Carolina) for first degree murder and first degree burglary. Defendant was sentenced to two consecutive life sentences. Defendant appealed as a matter of right pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27, seeking reversal of his first degree burglary conviction, a new trial on his murder conviction, or a new sentencing hearing on the burglary conviction.


OVERVIEW: The jury returned a guilty verdict for first degree murder based on malice, premeditation, and deliberation. The trial court concluded that the jury's failure to return a guilty verdict under the felony murder rule precluded submitting the aggravating circumstance to the jury that the murder took place while defendant was committing burglary. Defendant threatened to kill his wife and beat her, breaking her ribs. When the wife was released from the hospital, she took her children and went to stay with her mother and stepfather, the victim. Defendant argued with the victim about visiting his children and killed him with three gunshot wounds. The court pointed out there was no double jeopardy because first degree burglary and first degree murder each required proof of another fact which the other did not. The court rejected defendant's argument that the trial court erred by finding, in aggravation of the burglary sentence, that the crime occurred while on pretrial release from another felony. The court found no error in the State's use of peremptory challenges to remove jurors who were not Witherspoon excludables but were ambivalent about imposing the death penalty.


OUTCOME: The court found no error and left defendant's two life sentences for first degree murder and first degree burglary undisturbed.

 

212 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Utilities Com. v. North Carolina Natural Gas Corp.


No. 660A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 630; 375 S.E.2d 147; 1989 N.C. LEXIS 7


September 12, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
January 4, 1989, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by North Carolina Natural Gas Corporation (NCNG) pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-29(b) from the Utilities Commission's (Commission) Final Order On Further Hearing entered on 25 September 1987 in Docket No. G-21, Sub 255.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner gas corporation sought review of an order issued by respondent, the North Carolina Utilities Commission (commission), which concluded that the value of gas-in-kind retained by the corporation was revenue; that the corporation was required to refund money collected pursuant to a line loss and compressor fuel charge previously assessed from other customers; and that the money collected be included in a margin protection account.


OVERVIEW: An "Industrial Sales Tracker" (IST) account was established to protect the corporation's margins. On the corporation's appeal of the commission's order, the court affirmed the order. Specifically, the commission's decision, that the value of gas-in-kind retained by the corporation was treatable as transportation revenues, was not arbitrary or capricious. Nor was it unsupported by the evidence. Because the IST rider was a part of the corporation's rate structure, it was proper to flow the overcharge into the IST. In addition, the court found that the commission had not engaged in retroactive ratemaking in excess of the commission's authority because the order did not require the corporation to refund monies that it was properly authorized to collect. Finally, the court decided that the commission's actions did not amount to an impairment of contract or an unlawful taking of property in violation of the state or federal Constitutions. The commission was only enforcing its prior order, and there was no taking without due process when the commission's order was reasonable and its benefit to the public outweighed any deprivation of the corporation's constitutional rights.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order issued by the commission and decided that the value of the gas-in-kind was revenue, that the corporation had to refund overcharges it had collected, and that the money had to be put into an IST account created for margin protection.

 

213 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


In re Lynette H.


No. 252PA88


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 598; 374 S.E.2d 272; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 702


November 14, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
December 8, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review and appeal of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(1) from a decision of the Court of Appeals, 90 N.C. App. 373, 368 S.E. 2d 452 (1988), which affirmed an order entered by Leonard, J., in District Court, Wake County, on 6 August 1987, nunc pro tunc, 28 January 1987, declaring N.C.G.S. § 122C-3(21)(ii), the statute which defines "mental illness" as applied to minors, unconstitutional on the ground of vagueness.



DISPOSITION: Vacated and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state sought review of a decision of the North Carolina Court of Appeals, which declared N.C. Gen. Stat. § 122C-3(21)(ii), the statute that defined mental illness as applied to minors, unconstitutional on the ground of vagueness.


OVERVIEW: The trial court ruled in open court that respondent child was not mentally ill within the meaning and intent of that term as used in N.C. Gen. Stat. § 122C-3(21)(ii). Upon that determination, the child was released from a mental facility. The announcement of that determination in open court constituted entry of judgment for purposes of determining when notice of appeal had to be given, even if a formal written order was not filed until a later date. The state neither gave oral notice of appeal at the hearing nor filed a written notice of appeal within 10 days following the ruling. Thus, the court held that the state lost its right to appeal because it failed to give timely notice. The court further held that the trial court's ruling that respondent was not mentally ill concluded the case or controversy between the state and the respondent. The court held that upon that determination respondent was entitled to be released from the facility under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 122C-223 (1986). The court thus had no case or controversy before it and no jurisdiction to enter the subsequent order on wholly different grounds from those announced in open court, declaring the statute unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court vacated and remanded the decision of the lower court.

 

214 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Fullwood


No. 37A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 371; 373 S.E.2d 518; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 622


February 8, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Additional Arguments Heard  
November 3, 1988, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Vacated by Fullwood v. North Carolina, 494 U.S. 1022, 108 L. Ed. 2d 602, 110 S. Ct. 1464, 1990 U.S. LEXIS 1309 (1990)


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) (1986) from a judgment imposing the sentence of death entered by Snepp, J., at the 3 December 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Buncombe County. On 13 November 1986 we allowed defendant's petition to bypass the Court of Appeals in an appeal from a conviction of felonious breaking or entering.
State v. Fullwood, 322 N.C. 472, 370 S.E.2d 239, 1988 N.C. LEXIS 313 (1988)



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction of first degree murder and felonious breaking or entering in the Criminal Session of Superior Court, Buncombe County (North Carolina), which imposed a sentence of death on recommendation of the jury and also sentenced the defendant to ten years in prison for breaking and entering.


OVERVIEW: The defendant was convicted of first degree murder and felonious breaking and entering and sentenced to death after a jury trial, in which evidence showed the defendant had threatened the victim before breaking into the day care center where she worked and slashing her to death. The jury found in aggravation that the murder was especially heinous, atrocious and cruel. On appeal, the court held the trial court did not err in failing to sequester witnesses, allowing the state to use its peremptory challenges to dismiss jurors opposed to the death penalty, or by allowing defendant's doctor's testimony that his wounds were self-inflicted. Nor was it error to exclude defendant's hearsay statements that the victim stabbed him. The trial court's instructions on mitigating circumstances allowed the jury to consider statutory as well as non-statutory mitigating factors, and it was free to disregard nonstatutory mitigating circumstances under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000(f)(9)(1988). The court concluded defendant's trial was fair and free of prejudicial error, the evidence supported the aggravating circumstance, and the death sentence was proportionate and not excessive.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the convictions for first degree murder and felonious breaking and entering and found no error in the imposition of the sentence of death.

 

215 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hunt


No. 5A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 407; 373 S.E.2d 400; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 628


May 11, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Additional Arguments Heard  
November 3, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendants pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgments imposing sentences of death entered by Clark, J., at the 18 November 1985 Session of Superior Court, Robeson County. The defendants' motions to bypass the Court of Appeals as to lesser sentences were allowed pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31(b).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the judgments of the Superior Court, Robeson County (North Carolina), which convicted them of murder and conspiracy to commit murder and sentenced them to death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the trial court erred in denying his motion for a change of venue. Codefendant contended that the murder charges against him should have been dismissed. Both defendants alleged that the trial court erred in refusing to sever their trials. However, the court rejected their contentions. As to the motion for a change of venue, the court held that the trial court did not err in concluding that defendant had failed to show that it was reasonably likely that prospective jurors would have based their decision in the case upon pretrial information rather than the evidence presented at trial. Further, the court found that there was evidence to support the jury's conclusion that codefendant had aided and abetted in the commission of the murders by being present when the killings occurred with the intent to aid defendant in the commission of the offenses and with defendant's awareness of that intent. Finally, the court concluded that the trial court did not err in refusing to sever defendants' trials.


OUTCOME: Defendants' convictions for murder and conspiracy to commit murder and their death sentences were affirmed.

 

216 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Allen


No. 70A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 208; 372 S.E.2d 855; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 603


April 11, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 6, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from a death sentence imposed by Pope, J., at the 4 November 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Halifax County. The defendant's motion to bypass the Court of Appeals was allowed in those cases in which sentences of less than life were imposed.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Superior Court, Halifax County (North Carolina), which imposed a death sentence upon defendant's conviction for the first degree murder of a law enforcement officer while in the line of duty.


OVERVIEW: Defendant stopped his van behind a highway trooper and shot the defenseless trooper point blank three times. The jury convicted defendant of the murder of a law enforcement officer who was engaged in the performance of his duty to avoid lawful arrest for a violent crime spree and imposed a death sentence. On appeal, the court found no errors in either phase of the trial. The court held that: 1) the trial court properly declined to suppress defendant's voluntary confession; 2) the peremptory challenges were not racially motivated and were properly used to excuse veniremen with qualms about the death penalty; 3) the venirewoman opposed to the death penalty was correctly excused for cause; 4) defendant was not deprived of his right to be present at every stage of the trial; 5) a juror who had heard other people discuss the case was properly removed; 6) defendant was not prejudiced by the widow's testimony and a pistol demonstration; 7) the prosecutor's jury arguments were not improper; 8) defendant's mental capacity was not impaired; 9) the jury instructions that unanimity was required to find mitigating circumstances were proper; and 10) the sentence was not disproportionate.


OUTCOME: The court determined that there was no error in the guilt or penalty phase of the trial sufficient to require a new trial or sentencing hearing.

 

217 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Cummings


No. 65A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 181; 372 S.E.2d 541; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 605


April 12, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 6, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgment sentencing him to death on his conviction of murder in the first degree, said judgment imposed by Preston, J., at the 19 January 1987 session of Superior Court, Robeson County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Superior Court of Robeson County (North Carolina), which convicted defendant of first-degree murder and sentenced him to death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant voluntarily interjected himself into a dispute between two men and, in concert with one of them, plotted and carried out the killing of the other in the other's kitchen. The trial court convicted defendant of first-degree murder and sentenced him to death. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that the trial court properly denied defendant's motion to dismiss because the evidence tended to show that defendant calmly volunteered his services as an assassin shortly after the men had a dispute, worked out the details of the crime with the man's help, planned a ruse to gain access to the victim, and announced his deadly intention to the victim before shooting him with a .22-caliber pistol. The court also held that the sentence was proportional because the jury properly found that defendant had been previously convicted of another capital felony, an aggravating circumstance and did not find any mitigating circumstances.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the trial court, which had convicted defendant of first-degree murder and sentenced him to death.

 

218 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Hall v. Post


No. 340PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 259; 372 S.E.2d 711; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 611; 15 Media L. Rep. 2329


November 11, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 6, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review of the decision of the Court of Appeals, 85 N.C. App. 610, 355 S.E. 2d 819 (1987), reversing summary judgment entered by Fountain, J., on 20 May 1986 in Superior Court, Lincoln County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellees, adoptive mother and daughter, filed an action against appellants, journalist and newspaper, alleging the tortious invasion of their privacy by truthful public disclosure of private facts. The North Carolina Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of the journalist and newspaper, who appealed.


OVERVIEW: The adoptive mother and daughter were the subjects of a true story about carnival workers who had abandoned their daughter as an infant and left her with a babysitter, identified as the adoptive mother. The adoptive mother and daughter claimed that the public disclosure of these acts caused them embarrassment and that they had to seek counseling as a result. The journalist and newspaper claimed that the tort of public disclosure of private facts should not be recognized by the common law of North Carolina. The court agreed and reversed. The court held that tort was not recognized by the common law and that decisions of the United States Supreme Court, scholarly articles, and the Restatement of Torts made it clear that the private facts branch of the invasion of privacy tort was, at the very best, constitutionally suspect. Further, the branch of the tort that the court was asked to adopt would duplicate or overlap other torts, such as the intentional infliction of emotional distress. Since the adoptive mother and daughter would only be entitled to recover once, if at all, it seemed that recognition of the private facts tort would deliver nothing of any real value.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' decision reversing the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of the journalist and newspaper.

 

219 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Mayes


No. 514A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 159; 371 S.E.2d 476; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 535


May 12, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
September 7, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On defendant's petition for discretionary review pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 of a decision of the Court of Appeals, 86 N.C. App. 569, 359 S.E. 2d 30 (1987), affirming a judgment entered by Owens, J., at the 19 August 1986 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Cleveland County, upon defendant's conviction by a jury on two counts of disseminating obscenity in violation of N.C.G.S. § 14-190.1.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed a superior court's conviction of defendant for disseminating obscenity in violation of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-190.1.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged and convicted of disseminating obscenity. Defendant appealed the conviction on grounds that a superior court erred in failing properly to instruct the jurors on the appropriate community standards to be applied in determining whether the two magazines were obscene, and whether the superior court erred in excluding not only evidence concerning contemporary community standards, but also expert opinion evidence relevant to the application of the obscenity test. The court affirmed defendant's conviction and held that defendant was not harmed by the exclusion of certain testimony when the same, or substantially the same, testimony was subsequently admitted. In addition, the court held that evidence of mere availability of similar materials was not by itself sufficiently probative of community standards to be admissible in the absence of proof that the material enjoyed a reasonable degree of community acceptance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

220 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. McLaughlin


No. 637A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 68; 372 S.E.2d 49; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 537


February 8, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
September 7, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from the imposition of a sentence of death and two life sentences, to run consecutively, upon defendant's conviction of three separate charges of first-degree murder entered by Hobgood, Hamilton H., J., at the 10 September 1984 special term of Superior Court, Bladen County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his convictions from the Superior Court, Bladen County (North Carolina) for three murders. Defendant was sentenced to death for one murder and to life imprisonment for the other two murders.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was hired to commit a contract murder. As a result of the contract killing, two further murders occurred in an effort to eliminate witnesses and evade justice. Defendant was found guilty of first-degree murder and sentenced to death for one murder and to life imprisonment on the other two murders. Defendant appealed. The court found no errors. The court held that defendant's pretrial motions for an investigator and an independent psychiatric evaluation were properly denied because defendant failed to show that specific evidence was reasonably available or necessary for a proper defense. Likewise, the court's refusal to provide defendant with a jury selection expert did not deny defendant his sixth amendment right. Also, there was no showing of racial discrimination in the selection of jurors. Additionally, the court properly submitted aggravating factors to the jury and did not err in withholding mitigating factors. Further, defendant was not prejudiced by the excusal of a juror between the guilt-innocence in sentencing phase. Finally, the imposition of death for contract murder was not disproportionate.


OUTCOME: The court found no error in the imposition of a sentence of death and two life sentences upon the defendant's conviction of three separate charges of first-degree murder.

 

221 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. McKoy


No. 585A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


323 N.C. 1; 372 S.E.2d 12; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 583


March 14, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court; August 22, 1988, Additional Arguments Heard  
September 7, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from a judgment imposing a death sentence entered by Freeman, J., at the 29 July 1985 session of Superior Court, Stanly County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Upon finding defendant guilty of first-degree murder, the jury recommended the death penalty. The Superior Court of Stanly County (North Carolina) entered a judgment imposing a death sentence. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: After police responded to a reported disturbance at his home, defendant threatened to kill them if they did not leave. Although he was blind in one eye, defendant killed a deputy sheriff with one shot from a distance. After he was treated for wounds to his forehead and buttocks, defendant orally waived his Miranda rights, but refused to sign a written waiver because his head injury prevented him from seeing the waiver form. Defendant then confessed to the crime. Finding no error in either the guilt or sentencing phase, the state supreme court affirmed defendant's conviction and death sentence. Pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000(d)(2) (1983), the court first held that the record supported the aggravating circumstances that defendant previously had been convicted of a felony involving violence and that the murder was committed against a deputy sheriff while engaged in the performance of official duties. Next, nothing in the record suggested that the death sentence was imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor. Finally, given the facts of the case and defendant's history, the death sentence was not an excessive or disproportionate penalty.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's first-degree murder conviction and death sentence.

 

222 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Carter


No. 40A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 709; 370 S.E.2d 553; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 477


March 15, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 28, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgments sentencing him to consecutive terms of life for conviction of rape in the first degree and thirty years for conviction of kidnapping in the first degree and to a term of two years, to run concurrently with the sentence for kidnapping, for conviction of misdemeanor assault, said sentences imposed by Lee, J., at the 3 November 1986 session of Superior Court, Orange County.



DISPOSITION: New trial.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Superior Court, Orange County (North Carolina), which convicted him of rape in the first degree, kidnapping in the first degree, and misdemeanor assault. Defendant contended that the taking of a sample of his blood without a search warrant violated his rights under the federal and state constitutions.


OVERVIEW: At defendant's trial for rape, kidnapping, and assault, evidence was introduced regarding a sample of blood taken from defendant without a search warrant while he was in custody. On his appeal, the court reversed his convictions on all charges, holding that a nontestimonial identification order could not properly issue for identification procedures to be performed upon an in-custody suspect. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-14 did not apply to the taking of the blood sample from defendant. There were no exigent circumstances to justify a warrantless search, and no search warrant authorizing the taking of defendant's blood was issued. Obtaining the sample of defendant's blood violated his rights under N.C. Const. art. I, § 20 to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures, and the challenged evidence should have been suppressed. The court found no good faith exception to the requirements of N.C. Const. art. I, § 20 and granted defendant a new trial because evidence that should have been excluded under the state constitution was admitted at trial.


OUTCOME: Defendant's convictions for rape, kidnapping, and assault were reversed and he was granted a new trial on the grounds that blood evidence was improperly admitted in violation of the North Carolina Constitution.

 

223 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Chrismon v. Guilford County


No. 232PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 611; 370 S.E.2d 579; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 483


December 10, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 28, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On defendants' petition for discretionary review pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 (1986) of a decision of the Court of Appeals, 85 N.C. App. 211, 354 S.E. 2d 309 (1987), reversing the order entered by Seay, J., at the 24 February 1986 Civil Session of Superior Court, Guilford County (entered out of term and out of county by consent of the parties on 14 April 1986), denying plaintiffs' action for declaratory judgment.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court of appeals (North Carolina) reversed a trial court order denying plaintiff landowners' action for a declaratory judgment against defendants, an adjoining landowner and the members of the Board of Commissioners of Guilford County (board). The adjoining landowner and board members appealed.


OVERVIEW: The adjoining landowner sold a parcel to the landowners, upon which the latter constructed a home. Throughout this time, the landowner carried out grain drying and storing and the sale and distribution of agricultural chemicals from his property across the street, which was zoned A-1 Agricultural. When the adjoining landowner expanded his business operations to additional land he owned next to the landowners, the landowners filed a complaint with the county inspections department. As a result, the adjoining landowner was informed that his tract constituted an impermissible expansion of a nonconforming use. The landowner successfully sought a conditional use permit. The court held 1) while the rezoning admittedly constituted a form of spot zoning, it was legal because there was a reasonable basis for the county's action--the degree of public benefit created by the zoning action and the similarity of the proposed use of the tracts under the new conditional use zone to the uses in the surrounding areas, and 2) the zoning was not illegal contract zoning because the zoning authority neither entered into a bilateral contract nor abandoned its position as an independent decision-maker.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals' decision and remanded the case to that court for further remand to the trial court for reinstatement of the original judgment denying the landowners' action for a declaratory judgment and affirming the zoning action of the board.

 

224 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. White


No. 599PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 770; 370 S.E.2d 390; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 487


May 11, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 28, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On the State of North Carolina's petition for discretionary review of the decision of the Court of Appeals, 87 N.C. App. 311, 361 S.E. 2d 301 (1987), which found error in defendant's trial before Ferrell, J., at the 15 September 1986 session of Superior Court, Mecklenburg County, and granted defendant a new trial on seven of the charges on which he had been convicted and remanded the case for entry of a new judgment on the remaining conviction.



DISPOSITION: 86CRS4863 -- Reversed. 86CRS4888 -- Reversed. 86CRS4902 -- Reversed. 86CRS4924 -- Reversed. 86CRS53468 -- Affirmed. 86CRS53472 -- Affirmed. 86CRS53473 -- Affirmed. 86CRS4916 -- Modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state petitioned for discretionary review of a decision of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which granted a new trial to defendant on seven counts of possession of stolen property and remanded the case for entry of a new judgment on his remaining conviction, also for possession of stolen property.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of eight counts of possession of stolen property after police officers discovered items that were not described in their warrant during a search of his home. Defendant appealed, claiming that the trial court incorrectly denied his pre-trial motion to suppress the items not identified in the warrant. The court of appeals granted him a new trial on seven of the eight counts and remanded for entry of a new judgment on the eighth count. The state appealed. The court reversed as to four counts and upheld the judgment on the three remaining counts. The items in the first four counts fell within the plain view doctrine. Before the search, police officers did not have probable cause to believe that they would be found, but when they saw the items during the search, they had probable cause to believe that they were evidence of criminal conduct because they were listed in county incident reports. The last three counts pertained to items about which police officers had to consult city police after the search had occurred. Because they had no probable cause at the time of the search, the evidence was improperly admitted and new trials were properly granted.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision granting a new trial to defendant on four counts of possession of stolen property and upheld the decision as to the three remaining counts of possession of stolen property.

 

225 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Boudreau v. Baughman


No. 409PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 331; 368 S.E.2d 849; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 366; 6 U.C.C. Rep. Serv. 2d (Callaghan) 1393; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P11,895


February 10, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
June 2, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On plaintiff's petition for discretionary review of a decision of the Court of Appeals, 86 N.C. App. 165, 356 S.E. 2d 907 (1987), affirming summary judgment in favor of defendants entered by DeRamus, J., at the 8 September 1986 session of Superior Court, Forsyth County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded in part, modified and affirmed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff appealed a decision of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina) affirming summary judgment in favor of defendants, a North Carolina chair designer and the designer's corporation, in plaintiff's action against defendants for negligent design, breach of implied warranty of merchantability, breach of implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose, and strict liability, based on the statute of repose, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 1-50(6).


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff, a Massachusetts resident, injured himself, while visiting Florida, on a metal chair manufactured by defendants, a North Carolina chair designer and the designer's corporation. Defendants asserted that plaintiff's action was time barred, as it was brought outside the time period prescribed by the North Carolina forum state's statute of repose. Summary judgment in defendants' favor was granted based on the statute of repose, and plaintiff appealed. The court held, pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 25-1-105(1) (1986), that application of the situs state's law, Fla. Stat. § 95.031(2), was proper because that was the place of sale, distribution, delivery, use of the product, and injury. Plaintiff's action was therefore not time barred. Summary judgment for defendant was reversed on the negligence and strict liability claims, for a genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether defendants proximately caused plaintiff's injury and whether defendants breached the duty of reasonable care in selecting the materials used for the chair's edge guard. Summary judgment for defendant was affirmed on the warranty claims because defendant was not in privity with plaintiff.


OUTCOME: Summary judgment in favor of defendants was reversed on plaintiff's claims of negligence and strict liability, as a genuine issue of material fact existed on the issues of proximate cause and reasonable care. The judgment was affirmed on plaintiff's warranty claims, for although plaintiff's action was not time barred under the application of the situs state's statute of repose, plaintiff was not in privity with defendants.

 

226 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. McLaughlin


No. 637A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


369 S.E.2d 57; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 374



June 2, 1988, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [*1] As Amended June 10, 1988. Withdrawn June 13, 1988.


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from the imposition of a sentence of death and two life sentences, to run consecutively, upon defendant's conviction of three separate charges of first-degree murder entered by Hobgood, Hamilton H., J., at the 10 September 1984 special term of Superior Court, Bladen County. Heard in the Supreme Court 8 February 1988.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Superior Court, Bladen County (North Carolina), which convicted defendant of three separate charges of first-degree murder and imposed a sentence of death and two consecutive life sentences.


OVERVIEW: Defendant participated in a contract killing and later killed the victim's wife, who had contracted for the initial killing, and the victim's daughter, who witnessed her mother's death. Defendant was convicted of three counts of first-degree murder and was sentenced to death and two consecutive life sentences. The court affirmed, finding that defendant received a fair trial and a sentencing hearing free from prejudicial error before an impartial judge and jury. The convictions and sentence of death were supported by the evidence, and the sentence was not disproportionate. Defendant failed to show a particularized need for a second independent psychiatric evaluation at the state's expense. The findings supported the conclusion that defendant voluntarily, knowingly, and intelligently waived his constitutional rights. Defendant failed to show that the jury selection procedure was not racially neutral or that there was a history of relatively few blacks serving on juries. It was not error to admit into evidence photographs, the expert opinion testimony as to the cause of death, defendant's fingerprints, and the iron pipe used by defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment convicting defendant of three counts of first-degree murder and sentencing him to death and to two life sentences, to run consecutively.

 

227 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Weeks


No. 777A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 152; 367 S.E.2d 895; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 239


October 15, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 5, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgment imposing two sentences of life imprisonment entered by Brown, J., at the 18 September 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wayne County, upon jury verdicts of first degree murder and of second degree murder.



DISPOSITION: No. 85CRS2447 Murder in the First Degree -- no error. No. 85CRS2446 Murder in the Second Degree -- judgment arrested.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order from the Superior Court of Wayne County (North Carolina), which convicted defendant for first and second degree murder.


OVERVIEW: Defendant challenged a verdict finding him guilty of first and second degree murder. On appeal, the court found no error regarding defendant's conviction for first degree murder but arrested the judgment regarding second degree murder because the jury found defendant guilty of first degree murder under the felony murder rule but made no finding as to guilt based on malice, premeditation or deliberation. Therefore, the court held that because the underlying felony was the murder of another person, the trial court could not impose an additional sentence upon defendant by sentencing him separately for that murder. The court also held that the trial court did not err in excluding defendant's self-serving statement that was solely in the possession of defendant's attorney. The court held that the state's evidence did not show and defendant failed to produce any evidence to show heat of passion on sudden provocation, thus the trial court did not err by failing to submit the possible verdicts of voluntary manslaughter.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for first degree murder but arrested judgment regarding the conviction for second degree murder because an underlying felony was the murder of another person which meant the trial court could not impose an additional sentence for that murder.

 

228 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Poor Richard's, Inc. v. Stone


No. 397A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 61; 366 S.E.2d 697; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 135


December 8, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
April 6, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by the state pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(2) from the decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, 86 N.C. App. 137, 356 S.E. 2d 828 (1987), affirming order of Battle, J., permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing Article 1, Chapter 127B of the North Carolina General Statutes.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor state appealed an affirmance by the Court of Appeals (North Carolina) of a judgment that held N.C. Gen. Stat. Chapter 127B, article 1 which regulated the civilian sale at retail of military property violated the due process and equal protection provisions of both the state and federal constitutions, and that granted plaintiff retailer summary judgment and a preliminary injunction that enjoined enforcement of the statute.


OVERVIEW: The retailer claimed that compliance with N.C. Gen. Stat. chapter 127B, article I would have caused irreparable economic loss in violation of N.C. Const. art. I, §§ 1 and 19. However, the court reversed the judgment finding the statute unconstitutional. The court began with the presumption that the statute was constitutional and concluded that the statute did not obstruct the retailer's fundamental right to earn a living as guaranteed by §§ 1 and 19. The court held that the statute was rationally related to a proper governmental purpose. Under the test it applied, the court found that the statute involved a distinguishing feature from other types of retail sales because it regulated military equipment that was not manufactured for civilian consumers, and the statute's licensing scheme protected against unauthorized transfers of military property. Using that same analysis, the court found that the statute did not violate the Due Process Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV. Also, the statute did not create improper classifications under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because it was reasonably based on the difference between military property and civilian goods.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that found the state statute that regulated military property sales by civilian retailers unconstitutional. The court found that the statute was rationally related to a legitimate governmental purpose, and that it neither violated the due process or equal protection clauses of either the state or federal constitutions.

 

229 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Anderson


No. 202PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


322 N.C. 22; 366 S.E.2d 459; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 123


November 10, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
April 6, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 of a decision of the Court of Appeals, 85 N.C. App. 104, 354 S.E. 2d 264 (1987), awarding the defendant a new trial upon her appeal from judgments entered 28 March 1986 by Lewis (Robert D.), J., in Superior Court, Catawba County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina) which ordered a new trial on the ground that the trial court committed reversible error by excluding certain expert testimony with regard to a study allegedly tending to show the average adult would not find the magazines sold by the defendant obscene. Defendant had been convicted of feloniously disseminating obscenity in violation of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-190.1(a)(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of feloniously disseminating obscenity in violation of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-190.1(a)(1). The court of appeals ordered a new trial on the ground that the trial court had committed reversible error by excluding certain expert testimony. The court allowed the state's petition for discretionary review. The trial court had sustained the state's objection to the proffered testimony of defendant's expert witness that in his opinion the average person in the community would not find the magazines sold by defendant to be patently offensive. The court found that the expert witness's study had not gathered any data which would have indicated whether the average adult applying contemporary community standards would find the materials to be patently offensive. The court concluded that the trial court had not abused its discretion in excluding the proffered expert testimony, either on the ground that it would not assist the jury in understanding the evidence or determining a fact in issue, or on the ground that defendant had failed to establish a proper basis for the expert's opinion testimony as to any fact in issue.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the holding of the court of appeals and remanded the case to the trial court for reinstatement of defendant's convictions for feloniously disseminating obscenity.

 

230 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Mitchell


No. 273A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


321 N.C. 650; 365 S.E.2d 554; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 223


October 13, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
March 9, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right by the defendant from a judgment sentencing him to death for murder in the first degree entered by Hobgood (Hamilton H.), J., at the 17 March 1986 Criminal Session of Superior Court for Surry County.



DISPOSITION: New trial.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a), defendant appealed as a matter of right from a judgment entered by the Superior Court for Surry County (North Carolina), which convicted him of murder in the first degree and sentenced him to death. Defendant was also convicted of armed robbery, aiding and abetting in armed robbery, and felonious conspiracy.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court awarded a new trial to defendant because the trial court's refusal at each phase of the murder trial to permit both counsel for defendant to address the jury at final argument constituted prejudicial error per se. Both counsel for defendant were entitled to address the jury at each point at which defendant had the right to present argument to the jury. Although the number of defense attorneys allowed to address the jury could be limited to three under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 84-14, the trial court could not otherwise restrict defendant's right to argue to the jury. The court held that the prejudicial error also applied to the noncapital charges because they were joined with the murder charge for trial. Therefore, defendant was entitled to a new trial on all charges. The court rejected defendant's contention that the trial court erred by denying his motion to prohibit the state from peremptorily challenging black jurors. The trial court also properly denied defendant's motion to require the court reporter to note the race of every potential juror examined.


OUTCOME: The court ordered a new trial on all of the charges against defendant.

 

231 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Green


No. 38A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


321 N.C. 594; 365 S.E.2d 587; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 112


November 10, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
March 9, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgments sentencing defendant to death for each of three convictions of murder in the first degree, said judgments imposed by Stephens, J., on 14 November 1985, Superior Court, Wake County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his convictions and sentence to death after a jury trial in the Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina) on three separate charges of murder in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: After a night of drinking in a bar with his girlfriend, defendant shot and killed three men. Taking his victims' wallets, defendant fled the state with his girlfriend, describing his crime to members of the girlfriend's family. Defendant and the girlfriend were tried together for the killings. The girlfriend was acquitted, but defendant was convicted and sentenced to death on three charges of first-degree murder. On appeal, the court affirmed the convictions and death sentence. The court held that: (1) the trial court did not deprive defendant of a fair trial by permitting joinder of the girlfriend's trial under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-926(b)(2) or by denying defendant's motion for severance under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-927(c)(2); (2) evidence of an earlier barroom assault by defendant was admissible under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 8C-1, N.C. R. Civ. P. 404 to prove defendant's character and disposition to commit a similar offense; (3) the jury could consider an aggravating circumstance under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000(e)(4) that a capital felony was committed for the purpose of avoiding lawful arrest; and (4) the death sentence was not a disproportionate penalty for defendant's crimes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and sentence to death on three charges of murder in the first degree.

 

232 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Wheeler


No. 281PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


321 N.C. 725; 365 S.E.2d 609; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 229


February 9, 1988, Heard in the Supreme Court  
March 9, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On writ of certiorari to review an order entered by Hight, J., at the 19 December 1986 session of Superior Court, Vance County, denying defendant's motion for appropriate relief from a judgment imposing a life sentence at the 28 October 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Franklin County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a writ of certiorari after the Vance County Superior Court (North Carolina) denied defendant's motion for appropriate relief from a judgment that imposed a life sentence for felony murder.


OVERVIEW: The state convicted defendant of first degree murder under the felony murder rule, based on the felony of discharging a firearm into an occupied vehicle pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-34.1. Defendant fired 14 shots, one of which entered a vehicle and killed the occupant. The superior court denied defendant's application for appropriate relief. The court found no error. Any rational trier of fact could have found that defendant intended to fire into the vehicle from the evidence that defendant pointed the pistol toward the vehicle and fired the pistol. Defendant's exculpatory statement that he did not intend to shoot into the vehicle was contradicted by evidence that he fired the pistol at the vehicle. Defendant's exculpatory statement did not entitle him to have the case dismissed. The intentional firing into a vehicle, which defendant knew to be occupied, supported a finding that the act was done in reckless disregard of the rights and safety of others. Because 13 or 14 shots were fired in the direction of the vehicle, a reasonable man could conclude that one of them was likely to have entered the vehicle. There was evidence of an intent to fire into the vehicle.


OUTCOME: The court found no error in the superior court's refusal to grant defendant's application for appropriate relief from a judgment that imposed a life sentence for felony murder.

 

233 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lloyd


No. 577A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


321 N.C. 301; 364 S.E.2d 316; 1988 N.C. LEXIS 7


December 10, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
February 3, 1988, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from judgment and sentence of death entered by Friday, J., at the 15 July 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Cherokee County. The defendant was charged in bills of indictment, proper in form, with robbery with a dangerous weapon and murder of Burton B. Cornwell, Jr. The jury found the defendant guilty of murder in the first degree and robbery with a dangerous weapon. Following a sentencing hearing held pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 15A-2000, the jury recommended that the defendant be sentenced to death for the murder conviction. The trial court complied with the jury's recommendation and also sentenced the defendant to a term of fourteen years imprisonment for the armed robbery conviction. From the judgment imposing a sentence of death, the defendant appealed to the Supreme Court as a matter of right under N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a). On 21 October 1985, the Supreme Court allowed the defendant's motion to bypass the Court of Appeals on his appeal of the armed robbery conviction.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed as a matter of right under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a), the judgment and sentence of death entered by the Superior Court, Cherokee County (North Carolina), in which the jury found the defendant guilty of murder in the first degree and of robbery with a dangerous weapon and recommended that defendant be sentenced to death for the murder conviction after a sentencing hearing held pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted for first degree murder and robbery and sentenced to death. On appeal, the court overruled all of defendant's assignments of error and held that: (1) the trial court did not err by prohibiting defense counsel from inquiring into prospective juror's religious affiliations and practices since the defendant had other means available to learn their beliefs about the capital punishment; (2) jurors were properly excluded because they stated that they could not follow the law or instructions if it would result in a death sentence; (3) any possible error in the trial court's ruling that excluded defendant's exculpatory statements was harmless because even if they had been admitted, there was no reasonable possibility that a different result would have been reached at trial; (4) the trial court properly instructed the jury regarding mitigating circumstances to be considered concerning the defendant's prior criminal record; and (5) the trial court did not err in refusing to provide funds for a private psychologist because the defendant did not make the requisite showing of a reasonable likelihood that it would materially aid in the preparation of his defense.


OUTCOME: The court held that no prejudicial error had been committed by the trial court, that the record supported the jury's finding of aggravating circumstances on which its judgment and sentence of death was properly based, that the sentence of death was not imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary circumstance and that the death sentence was not excessive or disproportionate to the penalty imposed in similar cases.

 

234 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Holden


No. 650A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


321 N.C. 125; 362 S.E.2d 513; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2568; 71 A.L.R.4th 585


June 8, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
December 2, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgment imposing sentence of death entered by Stevens, Judge, at the 26 August 1986 Session of Superior Court, Duplin County, where defendant was convicted of one count of first-degree murder and one count of attempted first-degree rape. Defendant's motion to bypass the Court of Appeals as to the rape conviction was allowed.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his convictions by the Superior Court, Duplin County (North Carolina) for first-degree murder and first-degree rape and his sentence of death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of first-degree murder and first-degree rape and sentenced to death. Defendant sought review, and the court affirmed. The court held that sufficient evidence supported defendant's convictions. Defendant was not denied his due process rights by the use of "death qualified" jurors, because no juror had been excluded on the basis of race. Also, the jury correctly considered a no contest plea by defendant in a prior trial as a conviction when applying aggravating circumstances. The trial court did not abuse its discretion when admitting testimony or photographs into evidence during trial. Finally, the court examined other cases where a similar defendant had committed a similar crime and found that in those cases the juries had imposed the death penalty and it had been upheld.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions and sentence.

 

235 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Treants Enterprises, Inc. v. Onslow County


No. 746A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 776; 360 S.E.2d 783; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2417


September 9, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 7, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendants pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(1) from the decision of the Court of Appeals, 83 N.C. App. 345, 350 S.E. 2d 365 (1986), affirming order of Lewis (John B.), J., at the 28 October 1985 session of Superior Court, Onslow County, permanently enjoining defendants from enforcing an ordinance of Onslow County.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, county, county sheriff, and county tax collector, appealed from the judgment of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina) that affirmed the decision permanently enjoining the enforcement of Onslow County, N.C., Ordinance Regulating Businesses Providing Male or Female Companionship (June 19, 1985) (ordinance), because it was unconstitutionally overbroad. Plaintiff adult entertainment company brought the original action.


OVERVIEW: The county passed the ordinance regulating "companionship businesses," in part, to restrict adult entertainment theaters that offered female "movie mates" to men viewing films in individual rooms. The county intended to prevent the use of the ostensibly legitimate businesses as shields for prostitution and pandering. Before the ordinance became effective, the adult entertainment company brought the action for injunctive relief. The superior court granted the injunction and the appeals court affirmed the decision. On review from that judgment, the court noted that the definition of the term, "companions" included individuals who provided assistance to the young and the infirm as well as "escorts," who were widely believed to provide sexual services. The court concluded that the appeals court correctly determined that the ordinance's regulation of "companions" was overbroad and violated N.C. Const. art. I, §§ 1, 19. Those provisions required that government regulations of trades and businesses have a rational relationship to a substantial government purpose. The court affirmed the judgment.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment upholding the decision to enjoin the county, the county sheriff, and the county tax collector from enforcing the ordinance regulating companion services. The adult entertainment company sought the injunctive relief.

 

236 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnson


No. 502A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 746; 360 S.E.2d 676; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2402


September 9, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 7, 1987, Filed
