PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) (1986) from judgments imposing consecutive life sentences for two convictions of first degree rape, entered by Lake, J., at the 30 May 1986 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Durham County. On 22 December 1986 we allowed defendant's petition to bypass the Court of Appeals in appeals from convictions of kidnapping, for which the trial court sentenced defendant to thirty years imprisonment, and two assaults, for which the trial court sentenced defendant to eight years imprisonment.



DISPOSITION: No error in the guilt phase; remanded for resentencing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Superior Court of Durham County (North Carolina), which convicted defendant of two counts of first degree rape, first degree kidnapping, assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill inflicting serious bodily injury, and assault with a deadly weapon. Defendant was sentenced to two consecutive life terms for the rapes, 30 years for the kidnapping, and eight years for the assaults.


OVERVIEW: The court allowed defendant to bypass the appellate court in appeals from convictions of kidnapping and two assaults. The court held that the trial court's admission of evidence which tended to show that he made a local phone call from the city where the crimes took place was harmless error. The court held that the purpose of the evidence was to discredit defendant's alibi defense, and the state had already presented considerable evidence to the same effect. The court affirmed the conviction, holding that the trial court did not err in instructing that the jury could convict him of the rape if it found that he employed a dangerous weapon or that he inflicted serious injury upon the victim. The court remanded for resentencing, holding that double jeopardy principles precluded defendant's conviction for both first degree kidnapping and the first degree rapes. The court held that the jury may have used one of the rapes to elevate the kidnapping from second to first degree. The court held that the trial court could arrest judgment on the first degree kidnapping conviction and resentence defendant for second degree kidnapping or it could arrest judgment on one of the rape convictions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction of defendant for two counts of first degree rape, first degree kidnapping, assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill inflicting serious bodily injury, and assault with a deadly weapon. The court remanded for resentencing.

 

237 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Emerald Isle v. State


No. 111A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 640; 360 S.E.2d 756; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2414


December 11, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 7, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right by defendants, pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(2), from the decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, 78 N.C. App. 736, 338 S.E. 2d 581 (1986), affirming in part and reversing in part the trial court's grant of plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment in a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of 1983 N.C. Sess. Laws ch. 539, § 1, entered 8 February 1985 in Superior Court, Carteret County. Defendants' petition for discretionary review of additional issues was allowed 6 May 1986.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, town and individuals, brought a declaratory judgment action in North Carolina to challenge the constitutionality of 1983 N.C. Sess. Laws ch. 539, § 1. The trial court found against defendants, state and individuals, and granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment. The appellate court reversed the portion of the decision allowing severance of the unconstitutional sections of the act and held that the act could not be severed.


OVERVIEW: In 1982, plaintiff town obtained a permit from defendant state and constructed a vehicular ramp over sand dunes and accreted lands. After completion of the ramp, vehicles could travel to beach areas. 1983 N.C. Sess. Laws ch. 539, § 1 limited the use of the existing vehicle access ramp to public service and emergency vehicles and pedestrians. Plaintiffs, town and individuals, brought a declaratory judgment action to challenge the constitutionality of ch. 539. The trial court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment. The appellate court affirmed that ch. 539 was a local act in violation of N.C. Const. art II, § 24, but reversed the portion of the trial court's decision allowing severance of the unconstitutional sections of the act and held that the act could not be severed. The court reversed and remanded and held that ch. 539 did not violate the North Carolina Constitution because ch. 539 was a general law and not a local act. Since the act was a not a local act, it did not violate N.C. Const. art. XIV, § 3. Restrictions on vehicular traffic contained in ch. 539 were intended to promote the general welfare of the public and were reasonably based to further that intent.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the appellate court against plaintiffs, town and individuals, and in favor of defendants, state and individuals, because the act restricting beach access was a general law and not a local act. Because it was not a local act, it was not in violation of the North Carolina Constitution. The case was remanded for further proceedings.

 

238 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Cheape v. Chapel Hill


No. 96PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 549; 359 S.E.2d 792; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2342


June 8, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
September 3, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by plaintiffs from an award of summary judgment and judgment on the pleadings for defendants entered by Lee, J., after a hearing at the 17 November 1986 Civil Session of Superior Court, Orange County. Judgment entered 3 December 1986. Defendants' motion to bypass the Court of Appeals was allowed 7 April 1987.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, residents, citizens, and taxpayers, appealed an award of summary judgment and judgment on the pleadings for defendants, city and its leaders, entered by the Superior Court, Orange County (North Carolina). Plaintiffs argued the Chapel Hill Act, 1984 N.C. Sess. Laws ch. 961, which allowed defendant city to engage in a joint venture not for a public purpose, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, residents, citizens, and taxpayers, challenged the trial court's award of summary judgment in favor of defendants, city and its leaders. Defendants made a motion to bypass the appellate court, which the court allowed. Plaintiffs asserted that the Chapel Hill Act, passed by the General Assembly, was unconstitutional because it was a local act regulating trade and because it permitted the city to engage in a joint venture not for public purpose, which was prohibited by the state constitution. The court held that plaintiffs' contention that their standing remained an issue was without merit, that the Chapel Hill Act (Act), 1984 N.C. Sess. Laws ch. 961, did not regulate trade in violation of the N.C. Const. art. II, § 249(j), that the agreement between defendant city and a development company did not create a joint venture, and that defendant city had the power to convey air rights. Although the Act may have had some impact upon trade, it did not regulate trade because all it did was empower the city to engage in economic development projects, and set no rules for, nor established any, control over any activity that could have been fairly called trade.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment, holding that the contention of plaintiffs, residents, citizens, and taxpayers, that their standing remains an issue was without merit, that the Chapel Hill Act did not regulate trade in violation of the North Carolina Constitution, that the agreement between defendant city and a development company did not create a joint venture, and that defendant city had the power to convey air rights.

 

239 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. McCoy


No. 31A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 581; 359 S.E.2d 764; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2320


April 15, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
September 3, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgment of life imprisonment entered by Beaty, Judge, at the 28 October 1985 Special Criminal Session of Rutherford County Superior Court.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed, pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a), the judgment of the Rutherford County Superior Court (North Carolina), which convicted him of murder and sentenced him to life imprisonment. Defendant challenged the jury instructions and the selection of the jury.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that his motion to quash the indictment should have been granted on the ground that the jury was not selected from a representative cross section of the community. Defendant argued that the process for assigning numbers to potential jurors resulted in a disproportionately large number of rural jurors and that 51.3 percent of blacks did not have rural addresses in the county. The court rejected this argument, holding the county was largely rural, the cities were small, and that urban dwellers did not constitute a distinct group in that county. Defendant also argued that the trial court erred by instructing the jury that it could infer malice, thereby relieving the State of its burden of proof on that issue. The court disagreed, holding that it was proper to infer malice where the jury found certain predicate facts: premeditation, intent, and use of a deadly weapon. The jury was instructed that it must find those facts beyond a reasonable doubt. Furthermore, the court noted that there was little of no evidence of sudden passion, adequate provocation, or self-defense. If the necessary predicate facts were found, it was appropriate for the jury to infer malice.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

240 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Martin v. Melott


No. 61PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 518; 359 S.E.2d 783; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2325


May 13, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
September 3, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by plaintiff from Preston, Judge, at the 1 December 1986 term of Superior Court, Wake County. A petition pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 and Rule 15(a) of the North Carolina Rules of Appellate Procedure to bypass the Court of Appeals prior to its determination of the case was allowed.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant governor sought review of the order of the Superior Court of Wake County (North Carolina), for appellee director, in the governor's action to establish that the governor had the power to appoint the director of an agency created by the legislature. The legislature had delegated to the Chief Justice of the SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA the power to appoint the Director of the Office of Administrative Hearings.


OVERVIEW: Appellant governor brought an action against appellee director that challenged the legislature's delegation to the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court the power to appoint the Director of the Office of Administrative Hearings. The trial court had entered judgment for the director and the governor sought review. The court noted that N.C. Const. art. III, § 5(8), provided that the governor had the power to appoint all officers whose appointments were not otherwise provided for. The court held that the appointment of the director was otherwise provided for, and the plain meaning of the constitutional provision did not give the governor that power. The court found that the appointment of the director was not an exercise of executive power and did not violate N.C. Const. art. I, § 6, which prohibited the Chief Justice from exercising an executive branch function.


OUTCOME: The order of the trial court, which upheld the constitutionality of the legislative delegation to the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Director of the Office of Administrative Hearings was affirmed.

 

241 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Cinema I Video, Inc. v. Thornburg


No. 49A87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 485; 358 S.E.2d 383; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2256


June 9, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 28, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On plaintiffs' appeal as a matter of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(1) and (2) of a decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, 83 N.C. App. 544, 351 S.E. 2d 305 (1987), affirming a "Judgment and Order" entered by Bailey, J., at the 3 January 1986 Regular Civil Session of Superior Court, Wake County.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff video stores instituted a declaratory judgment action that sought to have amendments to North Carolina's obscenity laws declared facially unconstitutional and further sought to enjoin defendant district attorneys from enforcing the statutes against them. The video stores challenged the decision of the North Carolina Court of Appeals, which affirmed the a dismissal of the action.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court affirmed the summary judgment holding the statutes constitutional under both the North Carolina and United States Constitutions. The court held that that although fact situations were readily conceivable in which N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 14-190.13, -190.16, and -190.17, if improperly applied, would be unconstitutional, the mere potential for overbreadth was not dispositive. The court concluded that the statutes here, while potentially beyond constitutional bounds if improperly applied, were not so substantially overbroad as to require constitutional invalidation on their face. Accordingly, the court affirmed the decision of the appellate court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court affirming the trial court's decision granting summary judgment, dismissing the video stores' action.

 

242 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Grace Baptist Church v. Oxford


No. 456A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 439; 358 S.E.2d 372; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2270


April 15, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 28, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review of a decision of the Court of Appeals entered 1 July 1986, affirming the judgment of Hight, J., in Superior Court, Granville County, holding the provisions of an ordinance of the City of Oxford valid. 81 N.C. App. 678, 345 S.E. 2d 242 (1986) (unpublished).

Plaintiff Grace Baptist Church brought this action to enjoin 1 enforcement of a zoning ordinance of the City of Oxford. On 17 September 1985, Hight, J., heard the matter without a jury and concluded that the challenged ordinance, as written and applied, did not violate the due process and equal protection clauses of the federal and state constitutions. The Court of Appeals affirmed. Plaintiff's petition for discretionary review pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 was allowed on 6 January 1987.


1 As neither of the parties has raised the issue, we do not decide the question of whether a party may seek an injunction against enforcement of an ordinance where it has failed to exhaust its administrative remedies. See Forsyth County v. York, 19 N.C. App. 361, 198 S.E. 2d 770, cert. denied, 284 N.C. 253, 200 S.E. 2d 653 (1973), in which the Court of Appeals held that defendant prosecuted for violation of a zoning ordinance failed to exhaust statutory remedies and thus could not challenge ordinance on subsequent prosecution. See also Elizabeth City v. LFM Enterprises, 48 N.C. App. 408, 269 S.E. 2d 260 (1980) (no collateral attack was permitted on validity of ordinance where defendants failed to exercise remedies available under the zoning ordinance).

 [***2]



DISPOSITION: Modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff church brought an action to enjoin enforcement of a zoning ordinance of defendant city that required it to have paved parking facilities off-street. The Court of Appeals (North Carolina) affirmed a judgment that the ordinance was valid. The church sought discretionary review.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff church was constructed at a time when Oxford, N.C., Zoning Ordinance, § 502.7.3 (1970), required paved off-street parking. The church brought an action to enjoin enforcement of the zoning ordinance of defendant city. The intermediate appellate court affirmed a trial court judgment that the ordinance was valid. The court affirmed and determined that the zoning ordinance bore a reasonable relation to the legitimate objectives of the police power by assisting with drainage, prevention of erosion, and appearance. The court also determined that the church had asserted an injury so that it had standing to litigate the question of equal protection, but it determined that the ordinance had not been selectively enforced either in the direct enforcement or in application that excepted facilities constructed before the effective date of the ordinance, which were "grandfathered" and thus not similarly situated to the church.


OUTCOME: The court modified and affirmed the decision that the zoning ordinance was valid in plaintiff church's action to enjoin enforcement of defendant city's zoning ordinance that required paved parking off-street because the court determined that the ordinance as written did not offend state or federal equal protection and due process.

 

243 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Beard v. The North Carolina State Bar


No. 94PA87


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 126; 357 S.E.2d 694; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2157


May 11, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 7, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On appeal by plaintiff from the judgment of Farmer, J., filed in Superior Court, Wake County, on 25 August 1986. The North Carolina State Bar's petition for discretionary review prior to determination by the Court of Appeals was allowed 7 April 1987.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff attorney challenged a judgment from the Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina), which had held constitutional the court-established Client Security Fund, requiring each attorney to pay $ 50 to the fund each year.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff attorney challenged the constitutionality of the court's establishment of the Client Security Fund and requirement that each attorney admitted to practice in the state pay $ 50 each year into the fund. For failing to make the 1985 payments, plaintiff's license to practice law in North Carolina was suspended by the North Carolina State Bar. Plaintiff did not challenge the validity of the structure and procedures of the fund, but contended that the payment was unconstitutional, because only the general assembly could have imposed such an obligation upon lawyers. The court affirmed, finding no constitutional violation. The inherent power of the court had not been limited by the constitution. To the contrary, the constitution protected such power. The general assembly had no authority to deprive the judicial department of any power or jurisdiction that rightfully pertained to it as a co-ordinate department of the government. N.C. Const. art. IV, § 1. Through its inherent power the court had authority to do all things that were reasonably necessary for the proper administration of justice, including the power to deal with its attorneys.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment from the trial court, which had held constitutional the court-established Client Security Fund, requiring each attorney to pay $ 50 to the fund each year, because the court had inherent authority to deal with its attorneys.

 

244 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Zuniga


No. 156A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 233; 357 S.E.2d 898; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2176


April 15, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 7, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant appeals as of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from a sentence of death for first-degree murder and a life sentence for first-degree rape. Defendant was tried on these charges before the Honorable Donald L. Smith and a jury at the 11 February 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Davidson County, and was convicted. The sentencing hearing was held before the jury and the Honorable Hamilton H. Hobgood, retired Superior Court Judge called in as emergency judge to preside on 18 February 1985.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following a jury trial, the Superior Court of Davidson County (North Carolina) entered a judgment that sentenced defendant to death for first-degree murder and life imprisonment for first-degree rape. Pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a), defendant appealed as of right.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of the rape and murder of his former employer's seven-year-old granddaughter. Finding that the murder was committed while defendant was engaged in the commission of the felony of first-degree rape, the jury recommended the death penalty. Defendant appealed. Finding no reversible error during the pretrial stage of the prosecution, jury selection, the guilt and innocence phase of the trial, or the sentencing hearing, the court affirmed defendant's convictions and sentences. Given the manner of the killing, the age of the victim, her prior relationship with defendant, the disparity in their sizes, and the fact that hair was torn from the victim's scalp, the jury was entitled to believe that the defendant premeditated and deliberated, for some period of time, the killing of the victim. Given the savagery of the attack on this defenseless child, the enormous suffering that she apparently suffered, and the relative significance of the mitigating factors brought forth by defendant, the court could not say that the death penalty recommendation was excessive or disproportionate to the penalty imposed in similar cases, considering both the crime and defendant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and death sentence for first-degree murder.

 

245 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Brown


No. 65A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


320 N.C. 179; 358 S.E.2d 1; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2180


April 13, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 7, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant appeals of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgment entered by Pope, J., at the 21 January 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Robeson County. Defendant was convicted of murder in the first degree and sentenced to death.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed as of right pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a) from the Superior Court, Robeson County (North Carolina), which entered a judgment convicting defendant of murder in the first degree and imposing a sentence of death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted in the trial court of first degree murder perpetrated by lying in wait under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-17 and was sentenced to death. On appeal, the court affirmed. It held that, as to the guilt-innocence phase of the trial, defendant received a fair trial free from prejudicial error. The trial court did not err in instructing the jury on murder in the first degree solely on the basis of lying in wait. There was ample evidence that defendant's announced intention was to kill the victim, that he walked alone to the window beside the victim's office, that he waited for the victim to bend down, that he shot the victim, and that the shot resulted in death. Even a moment's deliberate pause before the unaware victim was killed satisfied the definition of murder perpetrated by lying in wait. The court also held that there was no prejudicial error in the voir dire examination, the indictment did not fatally vary from the proof, and the trial court did not err by failing to instruct on second degree murder. The court also concluded that the sentencing phase was free from prejudicial error and the death sentence was not disproportionate or excessive.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the first degree murder conviction entered by the trial court and the death sentence imposed upon defendant. There was ample evidence to support a conviction of murder in the first degree solely on the basis of lying in wait. There was no prejudicial error in the guilt or sentencing phases of the trial and the court could not hold as a matter of law that the death sentence was disproportionate or excessive.

 

246 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Robbins


No. 599A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


319 N.C. 465; 356 S.E.2d 279; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2085


February 10, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
June 2, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgments sentencing defendant to death for each of two convictions of murder in the first degree and to consecutive terms for convictions of robbery with a firearm and kidnapping in the first degree, said judgments imposed by Hobgood (Robert), J., at the 24 October 1983 session of Superior Court, Durham County.



DISPOSITION: No. 83CRS10237 -- kidnapping -- reversed. No. 83CRS10238 -- armed robbery -- no error. No. 82CRS13882 -- murder of Williams -- no error in guilt phase; remanded for new sentencing hearing. No. 83CRS12055 -- armed robbery -- no error. No. 82CRS13883 -- murder of Quick -- no error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Superior Court, Durham County (North Carolina), after a jury trial, sentenced defendant to death for each of two convictions of murder in the first degree and to consecutive terms for convictions of robbery with a firearm and kidnapping in the first degree. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court found that there was insufficient evidence that defendant kidnapped the first of two murder victims. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-39. The court noted that the victim was left outside an apartment, alone with his car keys, for five minutes; that he sat quietly and made no effort to leave while defendant was in the bathroom with the door closed; that he did not appear to be nervous; and that there was no apparent reason that he could not have left. Any determination that defendant restrained or removed him by force or fraud against his will would thus be speculation. The court then reasoned that a jury might treat a defendant more harshly where the aggravating circumstance was supported by armed robbery and kidnapping than where it was supported by only armed robbery. The court concluded that there was a reasonable possibility that the consideration by the jury of the kidnapping charge might have contributed to the recommendation of the death penalty. The court rejected defendant's contentions regarding a Batson claim, pretrial identification procedures, certain testimony to which defense counsel had opened the door, and alleged errors in jury instructions.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the superior court that entered defendant's conviction for kidnapping. The court reversed the judgment that sentenced defendant to death for one of the two murders and the court remanded for a new sentencing hearing. The court affirmed all of the other convictions and sentences, including the death sentence for the other murder.

 

247 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Stocks


No. 543A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


319 N.C. 437; 355 S.E.2d 492; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2025


April 14, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 5, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. 7A-27(a) from a judgment imposing a life sentence entered by Brannon, J., at the 28 April 1986 Regular Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wake County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina), which convicted him, after a jury trial, of first-degree murder and denied his motion to dismiss for insufficiency of the evidence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed his conviction for first-degree murder and the denial of his motion to dismiss for insufficiency of the evidence. The court affirmed the conviction and the denial of the motion to dismiss, finding that defendant waived the right to appeal the issue by introducing evidence after the motion was denied and by failing to renew the motion at the close of all the evidence. Despite that waiver the court reviewed the evidence and concluded that it was sufficient to submit the case to the jury. Defendant was not improperly denied a mistrial based upon his illness during trial because the trial court recessed the trial to allow him to recuperate and when the trial re-commenced defendant announced that he was well and ready to proceed. The court concluded that defendant was not denied the right to a fair and impartial verdict and no mistrial was warranted. It was not improper for the trial court to provide the jury with a written copy of the jury instruction on self-defense because it also admonished the jury to consider that instruction in conjunction with all of the others the jury received.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the denial of defendant's motion to dismiss for insufficiency of the evidence his conviction for first-degree murder.

 

248 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Pearson v. Martin


No. 643PA86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


319 N.C. 449; 355 S.E.2d 496; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 2318


April 13, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 5, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review prior to a determination by the Court of Appeals granted by this Court ex mero motu pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31(a) and Rule 15(e)(2) of the North Carolina Rules of Appellate Procedure. Plaintiff appealed from summary judgment in favor of defendants by Herring, J., at the 15 September 1986 session of Superior Court, Wake County.



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed; vacated and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Discretionary review was granted as to plaintiff attorney's appeal of an order of the Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina), which granted summary judgment to defendants, governor, attorney general, and bar association president, on the attorney's claim that he was wrongfully denied his right to be eligible for judicial office.


OVERVIEW: The attorney was not considered for a vacant judicial vacancy based on his party affiliation pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-142. A democrat filled the position. The attorney filed an action against defendants, contending that his rights to be eligible for the position were wrongfully denied. The attorney sought a declaration that § 7A-142 was unconstitutional. The trial court granted summary judgment to defendants. Discretionary review was granted prior to the appellate court's review of the attorney's challenge to the grant of summary judgment. The court dismissed the attorney's appeal as moot, vacated the trial court's grant of summary judgment to defendants, and remanded the matter with instructions to dismiss it as moot. The attorney sought inclusion in a bar meeting that already occurred and sought a declaration that § 7A-142 was unconstitutional for the purpose of being considered as a candidate. The court was unable to grant that relief by determining the appeal. Rather, the action was moot when it was filed, and the trial court erred in addressing it.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed as moot the attorney's appeal from the trial court's grant of summary judgment to defendants on a claim for denial of the attorney's judicial eligibility rights. The trial court's order that granted summary judgment was vacated. The matter was remanded with instructions to dismiss the action as moot.

 

249 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Quesinberry


No. 407A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


319 N.C. 228; 354 S.E.2d 446; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 1929


March 10, 1987, Heard in the Supreme Court  
April 7, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. 7A-27(a) from a judgment imposing the sentence of death entered by Helms, J., at the 12 June 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Randolph County.



DISPOSITION: Guilt phase: no error. Sentencing phase: new hearing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The jury found defendant guilty of robbery with a dangerous weapon and murder in the first degree on the bases of both felony murder and malice, premeditation, and deliberation pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-17 (1986) and recommended a sentence of death. Defendant appealed from his conviction and from a judgment imposing the sentence of death entered by the Superior Court, Randolph County (North Carolina).


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant alleged, inter alia, that the trial court erred in its submission of two aggravating factors to the jury. The aggravating circumstances submitted to and found by the jury in the sentencing phase of the trial were that the murder was committed while defendant was engaged in the commission of a robbery, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000(e)(5), and that the murder was committed for pecuniary gain, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000(e)(6). Defendant contended that submitting both factors violated due process. The court affirmed the conviction and ordered a new hearing on the sentencing phase. The court noted that under the facts of the case, where defendant was convicted of first degree murder on the basis on premeditation and deliberation, the submission of the two factors was redundant. The purpose of the robbery was pecuniary gain, and the same evidence provided proof of both factors. Because it was inequitable to submit an aggravating factor that overlapped another, and because there was a reasonable probability that the erroneous submission resulted in the jury's recommendation of capital punishment, defendant was entitled to a new sentencing hearing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's murder conviction, but ordered a new hearing on the sentencing phase.

 

250 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Reese


No. 468A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


319 N.C. 110; 353 S.E.2d 352; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 1887


December 9, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
March 4, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant, pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a), from a sentence of death imposed by Barefoot, J., following a jury recommendation, upon his conviction for first-degree murder at the 9 May 1983 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Northampton County (judgment and sentence of death entered 18 May 1983; concurrent three-year sentence for conviction of felonious conspiracy entered 9 May 1984).



DISPOSITION: Case No. 83CRS187 -- Felonious conspiracy -- no error. Case No. 82CRS4976 -- First-degree murder -- no error in the guilt phase; sentence vacated; remanded for new sentencing hearing for first-degree murder.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Superior Court, Northampton County (North Carolina), convicted the defendant of felonious conspiracy and first-degree murder. The trial court sentenced the defendant to three years' imprisonment for the conspiracy conviction and to death for the murder conviction. The defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: The defendant confessed to participating in a robbery in which a woman was murdered. He was convicted of first-degree murder under both the theory of felony murder and the theory of premeditation and deliberation. On appeal, the court held that (1) the trial court committed no errors during voir dire or in excluding jurors for cause based on their attitudes toward the death penalty, (2) the defendant had knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently waived both his Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights before giving his confession statement to the police, (3) the trial court properly admitted into evidence photographs and slides illustrating the testimony of both the agent investigating the crime and the pathologist, (4) the evidence did not support the jury verdict of premeditation and deliberation, as the defendant denied participating in, intending, or contemplating the killing of the victim and there was no direct evidence that he did so, (5) the defendant was properly convicted of felony murder and felonious conspiracy, and (6) the defendant was entitled to a new sentencing hearing, as several aggravating factors had been improperly submitted to the jury.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the convictions, but vacated the sentence of death and remanded for a new sentencing hearing.

 

251 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Stokes


No. 553A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


319 N.C. 1; 352 S.E.2d 653; 1987 N.C. LEXIS 1829



February 3, 1987, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from a death sentence imposed at the 24 October 1983 Session of New Hanover Superior Court, Judge Stevens presiding.



DISPOSITION: Death sentence vacated. Sentence of life imprisonment imposed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction and death sentence from the New Hanover Superior Court (North Carolina) for first degree felony murder, armed robbery and felonious larceny, contending the evidence was insufficient to support the "especially heinous" aggravating circumstances and that the death sentence was excessive or disproportionate when considered against sentences imposed in similar cases.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted for first degree felony murder, armed robbery, and felonious larceny, and was sentenced to death by a jury. Defendant and three accomplices conspired to and did rob a victim at his warehouse and in the course of the robbery the victim was beaten severely, causing a fractured skull and death. Defendant contended that the death sentence was excessive or disproportionate when considered against sentences imposed in similar cases. The court found no error in the proceedings, but held that the death sentence was excessive and disproportionate as a matter of law. The court set aside the trial court's death sentence and a sentence of life imprisonment was imposed. The court found mitigating evidence that the defendant suffered from impaired capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct and that he was under the influence of a mental or emotional disturbance at the time of the murder. The court concluded that the case fell within the class of crimes for which juries generally recommended life sentences and held defendant was no more deserving of death than his accomplice, who had committed the same crime in the same manner, and had received a life sentence.


OUTCOME: The court vacated defendant's death sentence and imposed a sentence of life imprisonment. The court concluded as a matter of law that the death sentence in the case was disproportionate and found that the case fell within the class of crimes for which juries generally had recommended life imprisonment.

 

252 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Alford v. Shaw


No. 132PA85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


318 N.C. 289; 349 S.E.2d 41; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2659


December 18, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
October 7, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review, pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 from a decision of the Court of Appeals, 72 N.C. App. 537, 324 S.E. 2d 878 (1985), reversing judgment entered by Snepp, J., on 12 December 1983 in Superior Court, Mecklenburg County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals (North Carolina) reversed an order granting summary judgment to defendant majority shareholders in plaintiff minority shareholders derivative action. The majority shareholders appealed the order.


OVERVIEW: The minority shareholders alleged that the majority shareholders undertook fraudulent transactions to the detriment of the corporation. The company's board of directors appointed a special litigation committee to investigate the claims to determine if it was in the best interests of the corporation to pursue litigation, but the minority shareholders filed their complaint before the investigation was completed. The court held that its inquiry into the special litigation committee's judgment was limited to whether the committee was composed of disinterested, independent directors who acted in good faith, following appropriate investigative procedures, and that the burden was on the majority shareholders to establish that the committee was disinterested. The business judgment rule provided a yardstick to achieve a balance between the need to hold management accountable for legitimate wrongs committed against the corporation and the need to ensure that management was accorded necessary decision-making discretion. The majority shareholders made every effort to insure that the members of the committee met the requisite qualifications of independence and disinterestedness.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed because the entry of summary judgment was proper.

 

253 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Belton


No. 693A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


318 N.C. 141; 347 S.E.2d 755; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2579



August 29, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendants pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgments imposing life sentences entered on 7 September 1984 by Johnson (Lynn), J., after a joint jury trial at the 29 August 1984 Criminal Session of Cumberland County Superior Court. Belton's petition to bypass the Court of Appeals with regard to a judgment imposing a twenty-year sentence allowed on 13 February 1985.



DISPOSITION: No error in trial; remanded for new sentencing hearing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed their convictions for first-degree kidnapping, first-degree rape, armed robbery, and first-degree sex offense following a joint jury trial in the Superior Court for Cumberland County (North Carolina). Defendants alleged, among other things, that joinder was improper, that the exclusion of black jurors through peremptory challenges violated their equal protection rights, and that their jeopardy rights were violated.


OVERVIEW: Defendants forced two white women at gunpoint into one's car and drove to a remote spot. One defendant raped one woman outside the car, while the other defendant did the same to the other woman inside the car. They then left the women and drove away in the stolen car. Defendants were found guilty of first-degree kidnapping, first-degree rape, armed robbery, and first-degree sex offense. Defendants appealed the verdict. On appeal, the court affirmed in part and reversed in part. The court held that joinder of defendants' trials was proper under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-926(b)(2) because the defenses were not irreconcilable. The court found that the evidence was sufficient for one defendant's aiding and abetting of the other because he was at the scene and encouraged the assaults. The state's exclusion of black jurors through peremptory challenges did not violate defendants' equal protection rights because it was not shown that the jurors were excluded based solely on race. The court held that defendants' double jeopardy rights were violated because the charged rapes formed the sexual assault element of the kidnapping convictions. The court, therefore, remanded for resentencing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part and reversed in part defendants' convictions. Joinder was proper because the defenses were not irreconcilable. The exclusion of black jurors did not violate defendants' equal protection rights because the exclusions were not based solely on race. Defendants' double jeopardy rights were violated because the charged rapes formed the sexual assault element of the kidnapping convictions. The case was remanded.

 

254 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Sharpe v. Park Newspapers of Lumberton, Inc.


No. 56A86


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 579; 347 S.E.2d 25; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2417


April 17, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
August 12, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(2) from the decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, 78 N.C. App. 275, 337 S.E. 2d 174 (1985), which reversed a judgment entered by Ellis, J., on 11 December 1984, in Superior Court, Robeson County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court dismissed an action for declaratory judgment filed by the plaintiff minority shareholders against the defendant newspaper purchaser. The Court of Appeals reversed the trial court. The newspaper purchaser appealed.


OVERVIEW: When a company purchased a newspaper it gave promissory notes to the shareholders. One of the conditions of the notes was that the holder would not be allowed actively to compete with the newspaper. The minority shareholders filed an action in the trial court for a declaratory judgment with reference to their right to compete under the note. The trial court dismissed the complaint contending among other things that the minority shareholders did not demonstrate an actual controversy. The appellate court reversed and the newspaper purchaser sought review. The court determined that the shareholders, although expressing an intent to look into the possibility of starting a newspaper in competition never showed an intent to start the paper as such there was no demonstration of an actual controversy and the trial court properly dismissed the complaint for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the finding of the appellate court.

 

255 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Jones


No. 584A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 487; 346 S.E.2d 657; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2420


June 9, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
August 12, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Before Llewellyn, J., at the 3 June 1985 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wayne County, defendant was convicted of second-degree murder, first-degree rape, common law robbery, and breaking or entering. The defendant received a sentence of fifty years on his conviction for second-degree murder. A consecutive sentence of life imprisonment was imposed for the conviction of first-degree rape. A further consecutive sentence of eight years was imposed for the conviction of breaking or entering, and a concurrent eight-year sentence was imposed for common law robbery. Defendant appeals the life sentence as a matter of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a); his motion to bypass the Court of Appeals as to the remaining convictions was allowed 15 January 1986.



DISPOSITION: Vacated and remanded in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order by the Wayne County Superior Court (North Carolina), which convicted defendant of second-degree murder, first-degree rape, common law robbery, and breaking or entering. Defendant received a consecutive sentence of life imprisonment for first-degree rape. Defendant appealed the life sentence as a matter of right pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a).


OVERVIEW: The victim was strangled to death in her room. A witness had seen a black male wearing a cap ride up on a dark colored bicycle and park it near the victim's room. Another witness, who lived with defendant, testified that he left home the night of the murder on a red bicycle wearing a cap. Defendant confessed to the other witness that he had strangled the victim. Defendant challenged the first-degree rape conviction and the life sentence. Following the close of all evidence, the prosecutor proposed an instruction on first-degree rape. The trial court charged the jury on both degrees of the offense. The court found that the indictment against defendant was for second degree rape. The State made a binding election not to pursue a verdict of guilty of first-degree rape, thereby assenting to an acquittal of the maximum offense arguably charged by the indictment. The court vacated defendant's conviction for first-degree rape, finding that it was error for the trial court to instruct the jury on first-degree rape, to submit that offense as a possible verdict, to enter judgment of conviction for first-degree rape, and to impose a life sentence upon that conviction.


OUTCOME: The judgment of defendant's conviction for first-degree rape, and the life sentence entered thereon, was vacated. The case was remanded to the trial court for entry of judgment of conviction for second-degree rape and for appropriate resentencing.

 

256 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnson


No. 525A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 343; 346 S.E.2d 596; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2426


March 12, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
August 12, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal from judgments entered by Albright, J., 18 October 1983 in Superior Court, Guilford County. Defendant was convicted by a jury of murder in the first degree, rape in the first degree, and kidnapping in the first degree. Defendant was sentenced to death for the murder conviction, life imprisonment for the rape conviction, and forty years' imprisonment for the kidnapping conviction, all sentences to run consecutively. Defendant appealed the murder and rape convictions pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a). On 6 January 1984, we allowed defendant's motion to bypass the Court of Appeals on the kidnapping conviction.



DISPOSITION: No. 82CRS64664 -- first degree kidnapping -- no error. No. 82CRS64665 -- first degree rape -- judgment arrested. No. 82CRS64663 -- first degree murder -- new sentencing hearing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of order of the Guilford County Superior Court, North Carolina, that convicted defendant of first degree murder, rape, and kidnapping, and also challenged his death sentence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was sentenced to death, following convictions for first degree murder, rape, and kidnapping. Defendant sought review. There was no error in the trial court's denial of defendant's motion to suppress, and defendant failed to show that the trial judge abused his discretion in denying defendant's motion to continue. The court found no error in the kidnapping trial or sentencing. There was sufficient extrinsic evidence admitted at trial to support the jury's findings that the kidnapping and rape occurred in the instant case. The probative value of the evidence at issue outweighed any prejudicial effect it may have had and it was properly admitted at trial. The court arrested judgment on the rape charge, and granted defendant a new sentencing hearing on his conviction of murder in the first degree. It was error to have permitted the state's expert to testify that, in his opinion, on the night of the murder defendant was able to form the specific intent to kill the victim. Finally, the court held that there was no error in the trial judge's decision that a specific instruction on intoxication by drugs was not required.


OUTCOME: The court arrested judgment on the rape charge, and granted defendant a new sentencing hearing on his conviction of murder in the first degree. The court found no error in the kidnapping trial or sentencing.

 

257 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Lea Co. v. North Carolina Bd. of Transp.


No. 588PA85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 254; 345 S.E.2d 355; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2776


February 12, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 2, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review of the judgment entered 11 April 1985 by Ross, J. in Superior Court, Guilford County.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant North Carolina Board of Transportation appealed a decision from the Superior Court, Guilford County (North Carolina), which applied a greater than statutory rate of interest in calculating the additional compensation owed by the board to plaintiff landowner for its delay in paying for his property in an inverse condemnation claim.


OVERVIEW: On appeal the court agreed that the property owner was entitled to interest based on the delay in payment. In determining the appropriate interest rate to use for measuring the additional amount to be awarded, the trial court received evidence on various interests rates. The court ruled that the statutory rate was presumptively reasonable. However, the landowner could rebut the rate's reasonableness by introducing evidence of prevailing market rates and by demonstrating the prevailing rates were higher than the statutory rate. In determining the proper rate to apply, the court had adopted the "prudent investor" standard. From the record, it was evident that the trial court correctly applied the "prudent investor" standard and considered evidence of a proper composite of prevailing interest rates to arrive at an "average interest rate for the period of delay." The court found that the rate applied by the trial court was supported by its findings of fact, based on substantial competent evidence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision which granted higher than statutory interest to the landowner for the delay in payment for the property that had been taken.

 

258 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Mann


No. 755PA85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 164; 345 S.E.2d 365; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2781


April 17, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 2, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On the State of North Carolina's petition for discretionary review of the decision of the Court of Appeals, 77 N.C. App. 654, 335 S.E. 2d 772 (1985), which found no error in the trial of defendant before Hobgood, J., at the 30 April 1984 session of Superior Court, Alamance County, but remanded the case for resentencing.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed in part; reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following a jury trial, defendant was convicted of soliciting another to commit common law robbery. Defendant was sentenced to imprisonment for seven years for conviction of a Class H felony under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-3(b) (1981). Defendant appealed to the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which remanded the case for resentencing of defendant as a misdemeanant. The state's petition for discretionary review was granted.


OVERVIEW: Prosecution witnesses testified that defendant formed the original idea to rob the elderly victim, that he masterminded the plan, and that he counseled and enticed others to rob the victim. The victim was ultimately murdered during the robbery. At issue was whether solicitation to commit common law robbery was an infamous crime within the meaning of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-3. This statute subjected a defendant convicted of an infamous crime to punishment as a felon instead of as a misdemeanant. The court concluded that solicitation to commit common law robbery was an infamous crime within the meaning of § 14-3. The court thus reversed the court of appeals on this issue. The court affirmed that part of the decision of the court of appeals finding no error in defendant's trial. The court held that infamous crimes involved moral turpitude. When a defendant counseled, enticed, or induced another to commit as degrading an offense as theft from the person or presence of a victim by force or violence by putting him in fear, he committed an act of depravity and a crime involving moral turpitude. Further, there was no error in the trial court's jury instructions or sentencing determination.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed that part of the decision of the court of appeals finding no error in the trial of defendant's case for soliciting another to commit common law robbery, but the court reversed that part of the decision of the court of appeals calling for the resentencing of defendant as a misdemeanant.

 

259 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnson


No. 124A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 193; 344 S.E.2d 775; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2794


April 17, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 2, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Before Lamm, J., at the 26 November 1984 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Madison County, defendant was convicted of first-degree murder. Finding no evidence of any of the aggravating factors set out in N.C.G.S. § 15A-2000(e) which would support the imposition of the death penalty, the trial judge terminated the proceeding without a sentencing phase and imposed a sentence of life imprisonment. The defendant appeals as a matter of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction for first-degree murder under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-17 by the Superior Court, Madison County (North Carolina). Defendant alleged that the trial court committed error in failing to appoint a medical expert to assist in his defense, in "death qualifying" the jury prior to the guilt phase of his trial, and in failing to instruct the jury regarding specific intent, second-degree murder, and involuntary manslaughter.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of first-degree murder for poisoning his daughter. On appeal, the court affirmed the conviction. The court held that the trial court did not violate defendant's right to a fair trial by not appointing a medical expert to assist in the defense because defendant's sanity was not at issue nor did he show a specific or particularized need for an expert. The court found that "death qualifying" the jury prior to the guilt phase of defendant's trial did not violate his constitutional right to a fair trial based on United States Supreme Court precedent. The court held that the trial court did not err in failing to instruct the jury that specific intent must be found to convict defendant of first-degree murder because N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-17 conclusively presumed that a homicide perpetrated by means of poison was committed with premeditation and deliberation. On the same basis, the court held that the trial court did not err in failing to instruct the jury regarding second-degree murder or involuntary manslaughter. The court also noted that a lesser-included offense should not have been submitted to the jury because no evidence existed to support it.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for first-degree murder.

 

260 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Paige


No. 624A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 630; 343 S.E.2d 848; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2400


October 14, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
June 3, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendants from judgments entered by Rousseau, Judge, at the 11 June 1984 Session of Union County Superior Court.

The defendants were tried on indictments charging each with first degree sexual offense, first degree kidnapping, felonious larceny of a motor vehicle, and two counts of common law robbery. In addition, defendant Paige was charged with first degree rape. The defendants pleaded not guilty to all charges. At the close of the State's evidence, the court granted a motion to dismiss the first degree kidnapping charges and submitted second degree kidnapping to the jury. The State took a voluntary dismissal of the charges of larceny of an automobile. The jury found the defendants guilty of all the remaining charges. The trial court sentenced Paige to two consecutive sentences of life imprisonment for first degree rape and first degree sexual offense, plus thirty years for second degree kidnapping. He imposed a concurrent sentence of three years for each count of common law robbery. Lowery was sentenced to consecutive sentences of life imprisonment for first degree sexual offense and twenty years for second degree kidnapping, and to a concurrent sentence [***2] of three years for each count of common law robbery. Paige appealed the rape conviction and both defendants appealed the sexual offense convictions to this Court as a matter of right under N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a). On 21 March 1985 this Court allowed the defendants to bypass the Court of Appeals on their appeal from the kidnapping and common law robbery convictions.



DISPOSITION: As to Defendant Paige: Case No. 84CRS3129 (Stanly County 84CRS1699, first degree sexual offense) -- Judgment arrested. Case No. 84CRS3130 (Stanly County 84CRS1700, first degree rape) -- Judgment arrested. Case No. 84CRS3127 (Stanly County 84CRS1697, common law robbery) -- Judgment arrested. Case No. 84CRS3120 (Stanly County 84CRS990, second degree kidnapping) -- No error. Case No. 84CRS3121 (Stanly County 84CRS991, common law robbery) -- No error. As to Defendant Lowery: Case No. 84CRS3126 (Stanly County 84CRS1696, first degree sexual offense) -- Judgment arrested. Case No. 84CRS3125 (Stanly County 84CRS1695, common law robbery) -- Judgment arrested. Case No. 84CRS3124 (Stanly County 84CRS994, second degree kidnapping) -- No error. Case No. 84CRS3123 (Stanly County 84CRS993, common law robbery) -- No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed judgments of conviction from the Union County Superior Court (North Carolina), arguing that the trial court improperly denied their motions for change of venue to the county where many of the alleged offenses occurred and that the grand jury was without jurisdiction to indict them for the offenses that occurred in the other county.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and co-defendant kidnapped the victim before driving to a different county where they sexually assaulted her and robbed her of her remaining possessions. Defendant and co-defendant were tried on indictments charging each with first degree sexual offense, second degree kidnapping, and two counts of common law robbery. In addition, defendant was charged with first degree rape. On appeal, the court concluded the trial court did not err in refusing to transfer venue to the other county because all charges in the that county were dismissed prior to the hearing on the motion but that the grand jury lacked jurisdiction to indict defendants for offenses that were alleged and proved to have occurred in the county for which change of venue was sought. The indictments showed on their face that the grand jury lacked jurisdiction over the offenses charged. In addition, the proof established that the robbery counts occurred in the other county and, thus, the State's evidence rebutted the prima facie jurisdiction of the grand jury to indict defendants for the charges of common law robbery that occurred in the other county.


OUTCOME: The court reversed defendant's convictions for first degree sexual offense, first degree rape, and common law robbery and the co-defendant's conviction for first degree sexual offense and common law robbery but found no error on the remaining convictions.

 

261 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Godfrey v. Zoning Bd. of Adjustment


No. 182PA85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 51; 344 S.E.2d 272; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2402


October 14, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
June 3, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review of a unanimous decision of a panel of the Court of Appeals, 73 N.C. App. 299, 326 S.E. 2d 113 (1985), affirming a judgment entered by Hal H. Walker, J., at the 14 November 1983 Civil Session of Superior Court, Union County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant adjoining landowners sought and obtained discretionary review of a unanimous decision of a panel of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which found no error in an order of appellee County Zoning Board which purported to allow a continuance of a "nonconforming situation" in favor of a neighboring landowner.


OVERVIEW: Landowner obtained a tract of land that was zoned for exclusive farming purposes. Thereafter, he petitioned appellee County Zoning Board to rezone the tract, which was granted. However, appellant adjoining landowners objected to this as it affected their land negatively. Appellee later issued an order, which purported to allow a continuance of a "nonconforming situation" in favor of landowner. Appellants brought the action to court and the lower court found no error in appellee's decision, and then appellants sought and obtained discretionary review. On appeal, the court looked at the applicable legislation, which indicated that a situation could be designated "nonconforming" for purposes of continuation only if it was an existing lot or structure on the effective date of the ordinance or amendment at issue. The court observed that this was not the case in the instant action. Furthermore, landowners' circumstances did not qualify as a "nonconforming situation." The court determined that the lower court erred in finding no error in appellee's order. Therefore, the action was reversed and remanded.


OUTCOME: The finding of no error in appellee County Zoning Board's order was reversed and remanded because the landowners' circumstances did not qualify as a "nonconforming situation." Also, the land at issue was not an existing lot or structure on the effective date of the ordinance or amendment at issue.

 

262 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lachat


No. 243A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 73; 343 S.E.2d 872; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2413


November 19, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
June 3, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by the defendant from judgment entered on 14 December 1984 by Wood, J., in Superior Court, Forsyth County.

The defendant was tried on an indictment, proper in form, charging her with murder in the first degree. Upon her plea of not guilty, the jury returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree. The State then stipulated that there were no aggravating factors present. The trial court concurred in that conclusion and entered judgment sentencing the defendant to imprisonment for the term of her natural life. The defendant appealed to the Supreme Court as a matter of right under N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a).



DISPOSITION: Judgment vacated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order by the Forsyth County Superior Court (North Carolina), which convicted defendant of murder in the first degree of her 13-year-old daughter. The trial court sentenced defendant to imprisonment for the term of her natural life. The defendant appealed as a matter of right under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a).


OVERVIEW: Upon learning of her husband's business failure, defendant drugged and drowned the daughter. The issue was whether the prohibition against double jeopardy forbade a second trial of defendant for murder where her previous trial on the same charge had been terminated by a mistrial without findings of fact by the trial court showing that a mistrial was necessary. The court held that the trial court erred by denying defendant's motion to dismiss on the ground of former jeopardy and vacated the trial court's judgment. The first trial ended during the guilt determination phase when the trial court declared a mistrial ex mero motu. Defendant contended that a retrial would unconstitutionally subject her to double jeopardy for the same offense. The trial court denied defendant's motion to dismiss and commenced the second trial of defendant. The court found that at the time the trial court withdrew a juror and initially declared a mistrial during defendant's first trial, no necessity existed for such action. Defendant's failure to object to the termination of her first trial did not prevent her from receiving relief to which she otherwise was entitled on grounds of former jeopardy.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the trial court's judgment and discharged defendant from custody.

 

263 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Jackson


No. 351A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


317 N.C. 1; 343 S.E.2d 814; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2425


March 13, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
June 3, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Before Ellis, J., at the 20 February 1984 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wake County, defendant was convicted of first-degree murder. Prior to trial, the prosecution had announced that the evidence did not support the existence of any of the aggravating factors listed in N.C.G.S. § 15A-2000(e) upon which the jury could recommend the imposition of the death penalty. Therefore, upon defendant's conviction, the trial court entered judgment sentencing him to a term of life imprisonment. The defendant appeals as a matter of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his conviction and sentence to life imprisonment after a jury trial in the Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina) on charges of first-degree murder.


OVERVIEW: After defendant confessed to the killing of a woman, the trial court entered an order granting defendant's motion to suppress the evidence. The court reversed the order. With the confession introduced as evidence at trial, the jury found defendant guilty of first-degree murder. On appeal, the court affirmed the conviction. The court held that: (1) defendant's arguments concerning the admissibility of his confession were barred by the doctrine of the law of the case; (2) defendant was not entitled to 14 peremptory challenges for capital cases under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-1217(a) because the prosecution, before trial, announced that it would not seek the death penalty; (3) defendant could not prevail on his claim that the prosecutor unconstitutionally excluded blacks from the jury without proof that the prosecutor engaged in a pattern of systematic use of peremptory challenges to exclude blacks from the petit jury; intervening precedent from the United States Supreme Court could not be applied retroactively; and (4) defendant presented no evidence that the make-up of the venire panel from which the petit jury was selected violated the Sixth Amendment's fair cross-section requirement.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction on a charge of first-degree murder.

 

264 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Denning


No. 467A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 523; 342 S.E.2d 855; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2153


March 10, 1986, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 6, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(1) from the decision of the Court of Appeals, 76 N.C. App. 156, 332 S.E. 2d 203 (1985), affirming judgment entered by Clark, J., at the 8 October 1984 session of Superior Court, Bladen County.



DISPOSITION: Modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which upheld his conviction for driving while impaired in violation of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 20-138.1 of the Safe Roads Act of 1983. The trial judge, authorized by N.C. Gen. Stat. § 20-179 to impose one of five levels of punishment, found that defendant had a prior conviction for a similar offense within seven years, a grossly aggravating factor.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that because the trial judge considered as aggravating factors separate criminal offenses or elements of the charged offense, as permitted by N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 20-138.1 and -179, he was denied his constitutional right to a jury trial. The court held that defendant had no standing to raise this issue regarding § 20-179. The court found that because the factors before the trial judge in determining sentencing were not elements of the offense, their consideration for purposes of sentencing was a function of the judge and thus not susceptible to challenge under either the Sixth Amendment or N.C. Const. art. I, § 24. The court held that the legislature's amendments to the driving-while-impaired provisions in the Safe Roads Act excised all mention of prior or subsequent convictions from § 20-138 and removed that element to § 20-179, the sentencing provision. The court held that prior convictions were not an element of the offense but were merely one of several factors relating to punishment. The court found that the sentencing procedure of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 20-179 contravened neither state nor federal constitutional guarantees of a jury trial in criminal cases.


OUTCOME: The court modified and affirmed the order of the court of appeals because the factors before the trial judge in determining sentencing were not elements of the offense, their consideration for purposes of sentencing was a function of the judge and was not susceptible to constitutional challenge.

 

265 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Welch


No. 112A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 578; 342 S.E.2d 789; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2163


November 20, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
May 6, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by the defendant from judgments entered on 12 December 1983 by Beaty, J., in the Superior Court, Gaston County.

The defendant was convicted of attempted robbery with a dangerous weapon and first degree murder. He received a sentence of imprisonment for twenty years for the attempted robbery conviction and a life sentence for the first degree murder conviction. The defendant appealed the murder conviction to the Supreme Court as a matter of right under N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a). On 23 April 1985, the Supreme Court allowed the defendant's motion to bypass the Court of Appeals on his appeal of the attempted robbery case.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the order of the Superior Court, Gaston County (North Carolina), which convicted him of attempted robbery with a dangerous weapon and first degree murder for which he received a sentence of imprisonment for 20 years and a life sentence for the crimes respectively.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of attempted robbery with a dangerous weapon and first degree murder. The court affirmed the conviction stating that defendant received a fair trial that was free of reversible error. The court ruled that any error by the trial court in overruling defendant's objection to testimony by the co-defendant's wife or in denying defendant's motion to sever was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt due to the overwhelming evidence of guilt. The court ruled that the court's non-testimonial identification order to conduct a blood-test was issued in error because defendant was already in custody and violated his constitutional right to be free from unreasonable searches and seizures, however, the court concluded that the trial court did not err in admitting the evidence because the court refused to apply the exclusionary rule to the good faith violation of the Fourth Amendment. The court stated that the evidence viewed in the light most favorable to the appellee state was sufficient to prove the elements of premeditation and deliberation for first degree murder.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the defendant's conviction of attempted robbery with a dangerous weapon and first degree murder. The court concluded that the trial court did not err in overruling defendant's objections, the trial court did not err in admitting evidence of a non-testimonial identification, and viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to appellee state, the evidence was sufficient to prove the elements of the crime.

 

266 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Gardner v. North Carolina State Bar


No. 706PA84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 285; 341 S.E.2d 517; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2088


May 14, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
April 2, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by respondent from judgment entered out of session by consent of the parties on 21 August 1984 by Barnette, J., following a hearing at the 2 July 1984 Civil Session of Superior Court, Wake County. Respondent's motion to bypass the Court of Appeals was granted on 30 January 1985.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, an insurer and an attorney, filed a petition for judicial review of respondent state bar's decision affirming two ethics opinions which held that it was unethical for an insurance company's house counsel to represent the company's insureds. The Superior Court, Wake County (North Carolina) entered judgment in favor of the insurer and the attorney. The state bar appealed and its motion to bypass the court of appeals was granted.


OVERVIEW: On appeal the issue was whether the trial court erred in concluding that allowing attorney-employees of an insurance company to represent insureds was not an unauthorized practice of law as defined by N.C. Gen. Stat. § 84-5 (1985). The court concluded that it had jurisdiction over the issue because the court's jurisdiction to decide questions concerning the conduct of attorneys arose out of the court's inherent power to deal with its attorneys. The court held that the trial judge erred in his conclusion because a corporation cannot perform legal services for others and if an insurance company, through its employees, would appear for an insured, it would be appearing as an attorney for someone else, in violation of the ban of § 84-5. The court held that the bar's ethics opinion affirming its two earlier ethics opinions was not unlawful because it was not based upon an arbitrary distinction.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decision in favor of the insurer and its attorney and remanded the to the trial court for entry of judgment not inconsistent with the opinion.

 

267 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Rogers


No. 165A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 203; 341 S.E.2d 713; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 2137



April 2, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal as of right by each defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgments entered by Small, J., at the 5 March 1984 Criminal Session of Wayne County Superior Court. Defendants' motions to bypass the North Carolina Court of Appeals on the non-Class A felonies were allowed on 22 June 1984 as to defendant Rogers and on 16 August 1984 as to defendant Carraway.

Defendants were charged in indictments, proper in form, with first degree murder and assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill.

The State's evidence during the guilt-innocence phase of this bifurcated trial tended to show that Charles Thurman Hall was fatally shot shortly after midnight on 21 September 1983 in an apartment building parking lot at 611 East Elm Street in Goldsboro.

State's witness Captain Floyd Hobbs of the Goldsboro Police Department responded to the call concerning the East Elm Street shooting at 12:07 a.m. He proceeded to 611 East Elm Street and found the victim, Charles Hall, lying in the parking lot behind a pickup truck parked in front of Apartment 611-A. Captain Hobbs stated that the 611 East Elm Street apartment building is a two-story brick building containing four separate apartments.  [***2] These apartments are fronted by a large parking area which adjoins Elm Street. Apartment 611-A is the westernmost apartment. The western boundary of the apartment parking lot is marked off by a chain link fence. Apartment 611-D is located on the eastern side of the apartment building. Washington's Shoe Shop is located in the extreme eastern portion of the parking lot. Across Elm Street immediately behind a small gas station, there is a larger building which houses, among other tenants, the Pink Panther Lounge. Captain Hobbs noted that to the left of the pickup truck, beside the fence, there was an automobile and to the right of the truck, in front of Apartment 611-B, a yellow Lincoln Continental was parked. Hobbs observed a bullet hole in the trunk lid of the Lincoln and a bullet fragment lying near its flat left front tire. Goldsboro Police Identification Officer Andrew Pinto testified that he removed the Continental's left front tire and found what appeared to be a bullet fragment inside.

Jeffrey Dekeyser, testifying for the State, related that on 20 September 1983 between 11:00 and 11:15 p.m. he drove his car to Blondie Coley's apartment to attend a party.
