Ms. Coley resided [***3] in Apartment 611-A East Elm Street. Dekeyser stated that he parked his car in front of Apartment 611-A between the fence and the pickup truck. When he arrived, several people were standing outside the front door of Ms. Coley's apartment. Dekeyser testified that after parking his car he walked behind the apartment building to Ms. Coley's back door. He found more people socializing outside that door. Dekeyser managed to walk just inside the back door but decided to go back outside after seeing the crowd within. While standing in the doorway, Dekeyser saw George Edwards and Charles Hall near the front door making their way outside.

Dekeyser testified that he then walked to the front of the apartment and stood at the southwest corner of the building. He noticed Edwards and Hall talking to each other while standing in the parking lot a few feet behind the pickup truck parked in front of 611-A. Shortly thereafter, Dekeyser observed a 1983 white Cougar turn off Elm Street and pull into the parking lot. When the car stopped and the passenger door opened, the interior light came on enabling Dekeyser to recognize defendant Carraway as the driver of the car and defendant Rogers as the [***4] passenger who was leaving the vehicle. Rogers stood up, pulled his coat back, and walked around the rear of the car towards Hall and Edwards. Rogers walked to within three or four feet of the two men and spoke to them. Dekeyser testified that Hall, by his hand movements, looked as if he were trying to explain something to Rogers. Dekeyser stated that "then, just like out of nowhere," he saw Rogers pull out a large caliber pistol and begin to shoot.

When the first shot was fired Hall fell to the ground, and as Edwards ran between the pickup truck and the Continental a second shot was fired. At this point the witness Dekeyser ran behind the apartment building through a broken place in the fence to a carwash located on the west side of the apartment building. He there observed the Cougar going west on Elm Street. Dekeyser also testified that he heard a total of three shots fired.

SBI firearms expert James H. Evans testified that he performed tests on the bullet removed from the back seat of the Continental and the bullet found at the scene by an investigating officer. Agent Evans found both bullets to be .44 caliber jacketed hollow-point bullets and concluded that both bullets [***5] were fired from the same firearm. Sergeant C. E. Boltinhouse of the Goldsboro Police Department testified that after defendant Carraway had been arrested and released on bond she reported a .44 caliber magnum pistol missing from her house.

The State produced other evidence tending to show that Rogers and Edwards had argued on several previous occasions and that Rogers had physically threatened Edwards on one of those occasions at Edwards' Barber Shop. The State also offered evidence which revealed that Rogers had been looking for Edwards at the Pink Panther Lounge prior to the shooting and had continued to look for Edwards after the shooting. The State's case went to the jury on the theory that Rogers, with Carraway's knowing assistance, mistakenly shot Hall while attempting to murder Edwards.

Both defendants testified in their own defense. Defendant Carraway stated that on 20 September 1983 she and defendant Rogers returned to Goldsboro from Wilmington. That evening, they left her 201 North George Street residence to buy some items for a sick friend. They drove first to the Jazz-Mo Club to talk with Carraway's mother who worked there. Outside the Club, Carraway bought a .357 [***6] magnum pistol from Buster King because he was selling it for a good price. Without going inside to speak to her mother, Carraway then left and rode with Rogers to a grocery store where she bought some honey and lemon for her friend.

They thereafter proceeded to the service station located next to the Pink Panther Lounge to put some air in one of the Cougar's tires. Upon finding the station closed, Rogers drove the Cougar to the 611 East Elm Street parking lot and parked near Apartment 611-C beside the Continental. Rogers got out of the car which he had backed into a parking space and walked around the car, opening Carraway's door. Rogers and Carraway had started back towards the Pink Panther Lounge when Edwards approached Rogers and asked for a loan of money. When Rogers refused, Hall appeared and stated: "Man if you've got any sense you'll give him all your money." When Rogers refused again, Hall pulled out a gun and began shooting. Carraway testified that the first shot hit the Continental and that she and Rogers ducked in between the Continental and the Cougar. Carraway stated that she heard a second shot fired and at that point reached into her pocketbook and pulled out [***7] her recently purchased .357 magnum. Carraway testified that she fired the weapon, then ran out of the parking lot towards Elm Street. At that time, she did not know whether she had hit Hall. Rogers then slipped into the Cougar and picked Carraway up on Elm Street. The couple returned to her residence and left for Myrtle Beach where they intended to be married.

By his testimony defendant Rogers substantially corroborated Carraway's story. He explained that he parked the car at 611-C because he did not want it to get scratched while they briefly went into the Pink Panther Lounge for a beer. Rogers also denied arguing with George Edwards at his barbershop or looking for Edwards on the night before and the morning after the shooting.

Defendants also offered the testimony of Jeffrey Fennell who stated that at approximately 8:30 or 9:30 p.m. on 20 September 1983 he was at Ed Lewis's house with George Edwards and Charles Hall. He testified that Charles Hall was "acting wild" and had a weapon in his belt.

Both the State and defendants presented evidence on rebuttal. At the conclusion of all the testimony, and after counsel's closing arguments and the trial court's instructions to [***8] the jury, the case was submitted to the jury. The jury returned verdicts finding both defendants guilty of the first degree murder of Charles Hall and guilty of assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill George Edwards.

At the sentencing phase of the trial, the court submitted the following aggravating circumstance against each defendant for the jury's consideration: the murder for which the defendant stands convicted was part of a course of conduct in which the defendant engaged and which included the commission by the defendant of other crimes of violence against another person or persons. N.C.G.S. § 15A-2000(e)(11) (1983). The court also submitted to the jury two mitigating factors for defendant Rogers and eight mitigating factors for defendant Carraway. The jury retired and after due deliberation, returned a recommendation of death as to defendant Rogers and life imprisonment for defendant Carraway for the murder of Charles Hall. The court imposed judgments accordingly and further imposed a ten year sentence for defendants' assault convictions to run consecutively with the sentences imposed for the murder.

On appeal, each defendant has brought forward numerous assignments [***9] of error. When possible, similar assignments will be discussed together.



DISPOSITION: No. 83CRS15013 -- Rogers -- first degree murder -- no error in guilt phase; death sentence vacated and sentence of life imprisonment imposed. No. 83CRS15013 -- Rogers -- assault with deadly weapon with intent to kill -- no error. No. 83CRS15014 -- Carraway -- first degree murder -- no error. No. 83CRS15014 -- Carraway -- assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill -- new sentencing hearing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were charged with first degree murder and assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill. They were convicted by the Criminal Session of the Wayne County Superior Court (North Carolina). Their motions to bypass the North Carolina Court of Appeals on review were allowed.


OVERVIEW: Defendants asserted numerous grounds for relief on appeal, including errors by the trial court during voir dire, failing to suppress certain evidence, and improper consideration of an aggravating circumstance during sentencing. The court determined that there was statutory authority for allowing the prosecution to death qualify the jury prior to the guilt-innocence phase and that reopening voir dire was within the trial court's discretion. Upon that reopening for additional questioning of a particular juror, a peremptory challenge could be used against such juror. The court held that photographic evidence was properly admitted where the witness could testify that the photograph was a fair and accurate representation of what it depicted, even though the witness had not himself taken the photograph, and the photograph had not been taken at the time of the occurrence in question. The court reversed one defendant's sentence and remanded the matter for resentencing upon a finding that the trial court's finding of an aggravating circumstance was not supported by a preponderance of the evidence.


OUTCOME: Defendants' convictions for first degree murder were affirmed, but one defendant's sentence was reversed and remanded for resentencing where the trial court erroneously found an aggravating circumstance.

 

268 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Perry


No. 125A85


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 87; 340 S.E.2d 450; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 1908



March 5, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from judgment of Brannon, J., entered at the 17 October 1984 Criminal Session of Wake County Superior Court, imposing a life sentence and a fine of $ 500,000 upon a jury verdict of guilty of trafficking in heroin by possessing 28 grams or more of heroin.

Defendant was also convicted of conspiracy to possess 28 grams or more of heroin, conspiracy to manufacture 28 grams or more of heroin, trafficking in heroin by transporting 28 grams or more of heroin, and trafficking in heroin by manufacturing 28 grams or more of heroin. Defendant received sentences of 45 years in prison on the verdict of manufacturing 28 grams or more of heroin, and 45 years in prison on the verdict of guilty of transporting 28 grams or more of heroin. The court also imposed a $ 500,000 fine in each of the above trafficking cases. Prayer for judgment was continued, without condition, in both of the conspiracy cases. We allowed bypass of the Court of Appeals in these cases.

The State's evidence tended to show that at about 11:20 a.m. on 9 June 1982, Detectives J. H. Johnson and E. T. Bert, of the Raleigh Police Department, Drug and Vice Division, observed [***2] Edell Willis (hereinafter Willis) park a yellow Cadillac in the parking lot of the Woodland Apartment complex and enter Apartment 823-C carrying a small brown paper bag.

At about 1:30 p.m. on the same day Willis was seen by Detectives Johnson, Bert, and Weatherspoon leaving Apartment 823-C Suffolk Boulevard with nothing in his hands. He entered the Cadillac, drove out of the parking lot, and turned right onto Suffolk Boulevard. After traveling a short distance, Willis was stopped by Detectives O'Shields and O. T. Perry. About ten minutes after Willis left Apartment 823-C, defendant was seen leaving the same apartment wearing a dark hat and carrying a silver, shiny package which appeared to be six to eight inches long and three to four inches wide. Defendant left the parking lot in a gold and white pickup truck and turned right onto Suffolk Boulevard. His truck came to an abrupt halt between the apartment complex and where Willis's vehicle had been stopped by the police officers. He then backed down Suffolk Boulevard, stopped and abruptly turned left into a driveway between dwellings 810 and 812 on Suffolk Boulevard. Defendant was out of sight of the police officers for just [***3] a few seconds.

Sergeant Perry pursued defendant as he backed down Suffolk Boulevard and observed him behind 810 Suffolk Boulevard closing the driver's door of the truck with his elbow. Sergeant Perry then saw defendant back his truck straight across the driveway and into the back of the residence of 812 Suffolk Boulevard where the officer blocked defendant's vehicle with his police car. Defendant asked Sergeant Perry to retrieve his hat for him indicating that it was on the ground behind 810 Suffolk Boulevard. Defendant then told Sergeant Perry that he wanted to talk to "Shield." When Sergeant Perry responded that Detective O'Shields was not at the scene, defendant indicated that Detective O'Shields was in fact approaching.

When he arrived, Detective O'Shields advised defendant of his rights and asked him if he wanted to talk. Defendant replied, "I don't want to take the fall for all of somebody else's s---." O'Shields then said, "Are you talking about Edell?" Defendant asked O'Shields, "What will I get out of this if I talk to you?" O'Shields then told defendant that he would give the district attorney any information that he released to him, but that he could not guarantee [***4] him anything. Defendant said that he understood, but added, "I just don't want to take the fall for everybody else's mess." Defendant was asked, "What did you do with the package you carried out of the apartment?" Defendant replied, "How will you help me if I tell you that?" Before O'Shields answered, a detective located the package some yards away from the truck in some bushes. O'Shields then told defendant that they had found it, and asked, "Do you have anything else you want to say?" Defendant said, "No, but are they going into the apartment?" O'Shields replied, "They are going to obtain a search warrant."

Defendant told Detective O'Shields that Apartment 823-C belonged to his girlfriend, that he had a key to it, and that Willis had left an ounce or so under the bed in the apartment. He asked the detective not to tear up the apartment. Defendant said that he had nothing to do with the drugs and that his girlfriend was not involved. He further stated that Willis wanted to use the place. Detective O'Shields asked defendant if, other than the package he brought out of the apartment and the package he stated was under the bed, that was all he (defendant) knew about being in the [***5] apartment. Defendant answered that it was.

Further evidence for the State tended to show that Detective Weatherspoon, while searching behind 810 Suffolk Boulevard, found a shiny, foil-wrapped package in the bushes, free of dirt, moisture and debris. Detectives Johnson, Bert, and Weatherspoon were of the opinion that the foil-wrapped package in the honeysuckle bushes was the same package they had observed in the left hand of defendant when he left Apartment 823-C.

When the package was opened, the detectives found 390 glassine envelopes, each envelope or bindle containing a small amount of white powder which was uniform in color, texture, and appearance. J. F. Casale, an expert in the area of forensic chemistry, analyzed a sample of the white powder and found it to be a mixture of heroin and mannitol. The aggregate mixture of all the bindles was 82.9 grams.

The detectives also found a Carolina Power and Light bill and a Southern Bell bill in defendant's name with the address 823 Suffolk Boulevard on each. A key was found on defendant's key chain that fit the lock on Apartment 823-C Suffolk Boulevard. They also found $ 7,440 in his sock.

On 9 June 1982 detectives obtained a [***6] warrant to search Apartment 823-C Suffolk Boulevard. In the bedroom under the bed they found two large green plastic bags containing numerous items which the officers recognized as items used in packaging and repackaging heroin. They found mannitol, a common agent used in cutting heroin, rubber gloves, boxes with empty bindles or envelopes, a strainer, album covers, aluminum foil, scotch tape, rubber bands, measuring spoons and other items. They also found a plastic bag containing a white powder which was properly secured and later analyzed by expert witness J. F. Casale who found the white powder to be 26.3 grams of virtually uncut heroin.

Defendant offered evidence tending to show that he sometimes stayed at his girlfriend's apartment on Suffolk Boulevard, that he had known Willis since childhood, and that he had often done work on Willis's car. On 9 June 1982 Willis was in the neighborhood of Suffolk Boulevard and saw defendant's truck parked in front of the apartment building. Willis entered the apartment and they visited for a period of time. Defendant and Willis did nothing in the apartment except drink coffee and talk about general things and in particular about defendant [***7] putting a new engine in Willis's El Camino. Willis left the apartment. When defendant later left the apartment, he was carrying some bills and an envelope in his hand. Defendant drove into a driveway across Suffolk Boulevard from the apartment complex to check out an old car he was thinking about buying. He backed his vehicle near the old car and was there blocked in by the police and arrested. He was questioned by an officer who identified himself as O'Shields. He did not know O'Shields prior to this questioning. O'Shields asked defendant about a package and he responded that he did not know what he was talking about. He made no other statement to O'Shields, but stated that he saw an officer find a package, which appeared to be wrapped in smooth aluminum foil, in the woods.

After being taken to jail, he was at some time placed in the same area with Willis, and he asked Willis about the package that the police found in the woods. Willis then told defendant that he had hidden the package in the woods across Suffolk Boulevard from the apartments the night before and was in the neighborhood to get it on 9 June when he saw defendant's truck and decided to stop by the apartment.  [***8] Willis said that when he left the apartment he intended to drive around the block once or twice to see if the coast was clear but that he was stopped by the police before he had gotten very far.

Defendant was in jail when the apartment was searched, and he testified that he knew nothing about any of the items that police had testified were seized in the apartment. Defendant and his girlfriend, Linda Fay Watson, each had keys to and access to the apartment. He further testified that he had never conspired with Willis or had anything to do with controlled substances.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order from the Wake County Superior Court (North Carolina), which imposed a life sentence and a fine and found defendant guilty of violating N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a) for trafficking in heroin by possessing 28 grams or more of heroin. Defendant was also convicted of conspiracy to possess heroin, conspiracy to manufacture heroin, trafficking in heroin by transporting heroin, and trafficking in heroin by manufacturing heroin.


OVERVIEW: On appeal of the possession and transportation of heroin convictions, the court held that the evidence of defendant's control of the apartment where heroin and implements of manufacturing were found, in addition to evidence of the transportation of heroin, was ample evidence of actual and constructive possession to support an inference that defendant had the power to control the drugs and that he transported heroin. There was ample evidence to give rise to a reasonable inference that defendant manufactured the heroin by packaging it. The testimony of the expert chemist, in addition to the evidence of possession, manufacturing, and transporting, was more than ample to have supported a reasonable inference of trafficking. The court rejected defendant's constitutional challenges to the penalties imposed for the trafficking offenses. The court rejected defendant's contention that the trafficking offense amounted to double jeopardy with the other drug charges because the other offenses were distinct, and the amount was the determining factor in a trafficking charge. The court affirmed the circuit court's increase of defendant's bond during trial and his sentence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's heroin convictions, sentence, and the fine imposed.

 

269 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Freeland


No. 249A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


316 N.C. 13; 340 S.E.2d 35; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 1882



February 18, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant as a matter of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) from the judgments entered by Hobgood, J., at the 6 February 1984 Criminal Session of Alamance County Superior Court. Judgments entered 16 February 1984.

Defendant was convicted of first degree rape, first degree sexual offense and first degree kidnapping. Following the sentencing hearing Judge Hobgood sentenced defendant to terms of life imprisonment for first degree rape and first degree sexual offense, the sentences to run concurrently, and to a thirty-year term of imprisonment for first degree kidnapping, that sentence to run consecutively with the life sentences.

The State's evidence tended to show that defendant approached Elizabeth Boyd, the seven year old victim, while she was playing near her home. Defendant convinced her to accompany him to a nearby wooded area where he inserted his finger in her vagina. Subsequent to this act he raped her. Semen, consistent with defendant's blood type, was found on the victim's underwear.

Elizabeth told her mother, Ellen Boyd, that her assailant was a white male who was wearing a dark blue baseball cap and T-shirt, each with white lettering, a pair of [***2] blue jeans and a pair of blue and white Nike tennis shoes. She also recalled that he was carrying a radio-tape player. Wilson Boyd, Elizabeth's father, had seen defendant walking on the road in front of his house prior to the assault. Steve Johnson, who lived near the Boyd residence, saw an individual matching Elizabeth's description of her assailant cut through his yard shortly after the assault had taken place. At trial in defendant's presence Johnson stated that he did not see that individual in the courtroom.

After Elizabeth recounted what had happened to her Mrs. Boyd called the Sheriff's Department, told them her daughter had been raped, and described the assailant. Shortly after the Sheriff's Department received this description of the assailant, defendant, who matched the description, was spotted by Lieutenant Perkins along Highway 87 and stopped. Lieutenant Perkins asked that defendant accompany him to the Boyd residence to clear up a certain matter and defendant agreed. Upon their arrival Elizabeth was brought outside and identified defendant as her assailant. He was then arrested.

Defendant took the stand in his own behalf and gave alibi testimony which was corroborated [***3] by several witnesses. He denied any knowledge of the assault on Elizabeth.



DISPOSITION: Remanded for new sentencing hearing.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of the Alamance County Superior Court (North Carolina), which convicted him of first degree rape, first degree sexual offense, and first degree kidnapping. He was sentenced to life imprisonment for first degree rape and first degree sexual offense, the sentences to run concurrently, and to a 30-year term of imprisonment for first degree kidnapping, that sentence to run consecutively with the life sentences.


OVERVIEW: In defendant's appeal from his convictions, the court found no prejudicial error in the trial court's admission of opinion and character evidence by the seven-year-old victim's mother offered to bolster the victim's credibility. The trial court erred in allowing the mother to testify that the victim had a good character for truthfulness and could distinguish fantasy from reality, but the error was harmless. The trial court correctly refused to declare a mistrial after a detective testified that defendant asserted his right of silence following his arrest because the prosecutor was not attempting to capitalize on defendant's silence and a curative instruction was given. In revising N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-39(b) to make the commission of a sexual assault on the victim an element of the offense of first degree kidnapping, the legislature did not intend defendants to be punished separately for both first degree kidnapping and the underlying sexual assault. Defendant's convictions therefore placed him in double jeopardy. The case was remanded for resentencing, and the trial court was directed to arrest judgment on either the kidnapping or one of the sexual assault convictions.


OUTCOME: The court remanded the case for resentencing. It directed the trial court either to arrest judgment on the first degree kidnapping conviction and resentence defendant for second degree kidnapping or to arrest judgment on the first degree rape or first degree sexual assault conviction.

 

270 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. McClintick


No. 302A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


315 N.C. 649; 340 S.E.2d 41; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 1884


November 21, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
February 18, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from judgments entered by Sitton, J., at the 23 January 1984 session of Superior Court, Buncombe County.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Superior Court, Buncombe County (North Carolina), which convicted him of rape in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of first degree rape. The court affirmed, finding that (1) the trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the prosecutor to ask defendant questions on cross-examination regarding other rapes or attempted rapes in California because the prosecutor had a good faith basis; (2) it was harmless error to allow the prosecutor to ask a question of defendant regarding his use of another name to avoid prosecution in California; (3) the trial court did not abuse its discretion in failing to sanction the prosecutor for discovery abuses where defendant was not prejudiced; (4) the information and the bill of particulars were sufficient to put defendant on notice of the nature of the state's allegations; (5) the trial court did not abuse its discretion by allowing multiple corroboration witnesses; (6) defendant failed to preserve an issue regarding his corroborating witnesses where he did not record their expected testimony; (7) there was no evidence to support instructions for lesser-included offenses; and (8) defendant was not denied a fair trial where the trial court did not engage in any impropriety.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for first degree rape.

 

271 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Gladden


No. 342A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


315 N.C. 398; 340 S.E.2d 673; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 1885


February 6, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
February 18, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Before Tillery, J., at the 16 April 1982 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Onslow County, defendant was convicted of first-degree murder. Following a sentencing hearing held pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 15A-2000, the jury recommended that the defendant be sentenced to death. From the imposition of a sentence of death, defendant appeals as a matter of right. N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) (1981 and Cum. Supp. 1985).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to death, appealed his sentence from Superior Court, Onslow County (North Carolina).


OVERVIEW: Defendant had been involved in a romantic affair with the victim's wife before he killed the victim. The court affirmed the murder conviction and the death sentence, finding that the trial court did not abuse its discretion by choosing not to sanction the prosecution for misstatements regarding defendant's statement to police. The court held that photographs of defendant with the victim's wife were correctly admitted to establish the affair as a motive for the murder. The court found that the prosecution's opening statement was proper. The court held that defendant was not entitled under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 84-14 to present an additional jury argument after the prosecution's closing argument. The court found that prosecutorial comments on the evidence were accurate and included reasonable inferences. The court found that the trial judge's comments on the evidence were accurate. Finally, the court held that substantial evidence of premeditation and deliberation supported a conviction for first-degree murder. The court upheld the application of the heinous, atrocious, and cruel aggravating circumstance pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000(e)(9).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the murder conviction and the death sentence.

 

272 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Gardner


No. 390A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


315 N.C. 444; 340 S.E.2d 701; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 1900


February 7, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
February 18, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant appeals from a decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, 68 N.C. App. 515, 316 S.E. 2d 131 (1984), finding no error in defendant's convictions of felony breaking or entering and felony larceny. Judgments were entered by Ferrell, J., at the 17 January 1983 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Gaston County. Pursuant to Rule 21 of the North Carolina Rules of Appellate Procedure, we allowed defendant's petition for certiorari to review an issue which was not the basis of the dissent in the lower court.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the order of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed his convictions for breaking or entering and felony larceny.


OVERVIEW: Defendant claimed that during his cross-examination concerning his post-arrest silence the prosecutor violated defendant's right to remain silent. He also claimed that his convictions and sentencing in the same trial for felony breaking or entering and felony larceny violated the prohibition against double jeopardy. The appellate court affirmed defendant's convictions. On appeal, the court affirmed and held that defendant did not preserve for appeal an objection to his cross-examination. The court added that the cross-examination did not violate defendant's constitutional rights and that, where punishment was involved, the double jeopardy clause acted as a restraint on the prosecutor and the courts, and only prohibited a trial court from imposing more punishment than was intended by the legislature. The court concluded that defendant was properly tried, convicted of, and punished separately for the crime of breaking or entering and the crime of felony larceny following a breaking or entering when those cases were jointly tried.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court that affirmed defendant's convictions for breaking or entering and felony larceny.

 

273 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Henry v. Edmisten


No. 550PA84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


315 N.C. 474; 340 S.E.2d 720; 1986 N.C. LEXIS 1883



February 18, 1986, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review of a judgment entered by Barnette, J., at the 4 October 1984 Civil Session of Wake County Superior Court. We certified this cause for review prior to determination by the Court of Appeals pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31 and N.C. R. App. P. 15(e)(1).



DISPOSITION: In Case No. 84CVS2347, reversed. In Case No. 84CVS3414, modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff arrested drivers (drivers) had their drivers' licenses revoked pursuant to the Safe Roads Act of 1983, N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 20 et seq. The drivers filed separate complaints that alleged that the orders that revoked the licenses were unconstitutional. The Wake County Superior Court (North Carolina) consolidated the two actions and concluded that the pretrial revocation provision deprived the drivers of an interest in their property.


OVERVIEW: The trial court entered an order that enjoined the state from revoking the drivers' licenses. The court employed the three factor balancing test to resolve the due process issue. First, the court weighed the private interest that was affected and determined that the interest in the drivers' licenses was not insubstantial. The court then balanced the risk of erroneous deprivation of the private interest and the probable value of additional procedural safeguards. The court determined that the procedures provided a reasonably reliable basis for determining that the facts that justified the revocation were as alleged. Finally, the court weighed the state's interest and the fiscal and administrative burdens that would have resulted from additional procedures. The court held that the state's interest in highway safety outweighed the private interest involved and any risk of erroneously depriving those interests. The court determined that the 10-day revocation period was not punishment, but was instead a highway safety measure that gave the drivers all the process they were due and did not violate equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the extension of the revocation period of one driver and affirmed the remainder of the judgment.

 

274 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Brown


No. 565A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


315 N.C. 40; 337 S.E.2d 808; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1987


February 5, 1985, Heard in the Supreme Court  
December 10, 1985, Filed


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Writ of certiorari denied Brown v. North Carolina, 476 U.S. 1165, 90 L. Ed. 2d 733, 106 S. Ct. 2293, 1986 U.S. LEXIS 1726, 54 U.S.L.W. 3794 (1986)
Habeas corpus proceeding at, Motion granted by State v. Brown, 496 S.E.2d 397, 1997 N.C. LEXIS 872 (N.C., 1997)


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Before Smith, J., at the 7 November 1983 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Martin County, defendant was convicted of first-degree murder and robbery with a dangerous weapon. Following a sentencing hearing held pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 15A-2000, the jury recommended that the defendant be sentenced to death for the murder conviction. Defendant was sentenced to a consecutive term of 40 years imprisonment for the armed robbery conviction. From the imposition of a sentence of death, defendant appeals as a matter of right. N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a). We allowed defendant's motion to bypass the North Carolina Court of Appeals on the armed robbery conviction on 14 December 1984.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his conviction and death sentence from the Superior Court, Martin County (North Carolina) for first-degree murder and armed robbery for the robbery of a store and the killing of the store clerk.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was caught driving a car belonging to the victim after the victim's store was found robbed. Police found a pistol and cash in the car, as well as a toboggan cap with eye holes and a pair of ski gloves. He said he robbed the store and got the victim's car keys, but denied harming her. Defendant was convicted of murder and armed robbery and sentenced to death. The court affirmed the conviction and sentence. The court held that the failure to conduct a formal arraignment did not render the verdict or judgment invalid. There was probable cause for defendant's arrest. "Death-qualifying" the jury did not result in a biased jury. While N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-1214(j) allowed for individual voir dire and jury sequestration, it granted no absolute right to them. The North Carolina death penalty statute, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-2000 et seq., was constitutional. There was no error in submitting evidence of defendant's prior crimes. Admission of defendant's prior criminal history was proper as rebuttal. There was no error in referring to the jury's sentencing decision as a "recommendation." The court also found the sentence to be proportional to other similar sentences.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the conviction and death sentence.

 

275 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Cauble v. Asheville


No. 150PA84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


314 N.C. 598; 336 S.E.2d 59; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1985



November 5, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review, pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31, of the unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals, reported at 66 N.C. App. 537, 311 S.E. 2d 889 (1984), reversing and remanding the judgment entered by Lewis, J., on 14 October 1982 at Asheville, Buncombe County. The judgment was entered out of session pursuant to a stipulation of the parties.
Cauble v. Asheville, 66 N.C. App. 537, 311 S.E.2d 889, 1984 N.C. App. LEXIS 2925 (1984)



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court exercised its discretionary review, pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-31, of the unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which reversed and remanded the trial court's judgment. The action was brought by plaintiff citizen for himself and other citizens, who were residents and taxpayers of defendant city to compel the city to pay into the county school fund all fines and forfeitures paid for overtime parking.


OVERVIEW: The trial court denied the city a summary judgment, ordering that the county education board recover an amount equal to the clear proceeds of all penalties, forfeitures, or fines collected for violating parking ordinances. The appellate court held that the term "clear proceeds" as used in N.C. Const. art. IX, § 7 was synonymous with net proceeds and that collection costs should be deducted from the gross proceeds of monies received for traffic violations. On review, the court held that reasonable collection costs could constitutionally be deducted from the gross proceeds of overtime parking fines the city collected, asserting that the proper test to determine permissible deductions must bear a reasonable relation to the fine's collection cost. The court concluded that collection costs did not include those associated with enforcing the ordinance but were limited to administrative costs. The court opined that if the costs of enforcing the state's penal laws were part of collecting fines imposed by the laws, there could never be any clear proceeds of such fines to be used to support public schools, thereby contravening the constitution or being impractical. The judgment was affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's decision, which determined that the clear proceeds of all funds received from traffic violations must be paid to the county finance officer for distribution and held that the test for determining permissible deductions must bear a reasonable relation to the cost of collecting the fine.

 

276 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Square D Co. v. C. J. Kern Contractors, Inc.


No. 530A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


314 N.C. 423; 334 S.E.2d 63; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1883



September 5, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by plaintiff pursuant to G.S. 7A-30(2) from a decision of the Court of Appeals, 70 N.C. App. 30, 318 S.E. 2d 527 (1984), affirming summary judgment for defendants entered on 7 January 1983 by Lewis, J., during the 13 December 1982 Civil Session of Superior Court, Buncombe County.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowner sought review of the order form the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of defendants, contractor and architect, in an action for breach of contract and negligence.


OVERVIEW: The landowner entered into an agreement with contractor to construct an addition to a building on landowner's property. Also, the landowner contracted with the architect to design the addition. The landowner filed suit against the contractor and architect and alleged that the contractor negligently constructed the addition and that the architect negligently designed the addition and that both breached their contract with the landowner. The contractor and the architect filed motions to dismiss that were converted to motions for summary judgment, which the trial court granted. The appellate court affirmed the trial court's ruling and the landowner appealed. On appeal, the court affirmed the summary judgment and held that the 10-year statute of limitations under N.C. Gen. Stat. § 1-47 (2) did not apply the action against the contractor because there was no indication that the landowner and contractor intended their agreement to be a sealed instrument. The court further held that the trial court did not err when it granted summary judgment favor of the architect. N.C. Gen. Stat. 1-15(c) (1981), 1050(5) (1983), were not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court, which affirmed a summary judgment in favor of the contractor and architect in an action for breach of contract and negligence.

 

277 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Evans v. Roberson


No. 489A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


314 N.C. 315; 333 S.E.2d 228; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1781



August 13, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal of right pursuant to G.S. 7A-30(2) by defendant from the decision of a divided panel of the Court of Appeals, 69 N.C. App. 644, 317 S.E. 2d 715 (1984), affirming judgment entered by Freeman, J., in favor of plaintiff during the 23 August 1983 Session of Superior Court, Yadkin County.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff driver appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed the trial court's decision convicting the driver of seven violations of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 20-343 for unlawfully altering the odometers of seven motor vehicles with the intent to change the number of miles indicated thereon and which held that the driver was not entitled to a probationary license.


OVERVIEW: The issue on the driver's appeal was whether the Court of Appeals correctly affirmed the trial court's conclusion that because odometer alteration was not a moving violation it cannot serve as a basis for denial of reinstatement of driver's license following permanent revocation. The court found that the answer to the issue was no and held that the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial court's conclusion. The court held that the crime of odometer alteration prohibited by N.C. Gen. Stat. § 20-343 was a violation of the motor vehicle laws of North Carolina as that term was used in § 20-28.1(c).


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded the case to the trial court for a new trial.

 

278 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Primes


No. 694A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


314 N.C. 202; 333 S.E.2d 278; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1787



August 13, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On appeal from defendant's conviction of first degree murder, entered at the 21 April 1976 Criminal Session of Wake County Superior Court, Judge Godwin presiding. Defendant initially received the death penalty but was resentenced to life imprisonment on 15 October 1979 upon defendant's motion following the United States Supreme Court's decision in Woodson v. North Carolina, 428 U.S. 280 (1976), declaring the state's mandatory death penalty statute unconstitutional.



DISPOSITION: No error in the trial. Life sentence reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction from the Wake County Superior Court (North Carolina) for first degree murder. Defendant, who was a prisoner at the time of the alleged murder, contended that certain evidence was improperly admitted at trial because the evidence was allegedly obtained during an illegal search and seizure in violation of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution and N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-401.


OVERVIEW: Defendant allegedly committed a murder while in prison. Defendant was convicted of first degree murder and sentenced to death. After the Supreme Court ruled that North Carolina's mandatory death penalty statute was unconstitutional, defendant was resentenced to life imprisonment, but the sentence was later set aside. On appeal, the court affirmed defendant's conviction, reinstated defendant's life sentence, and held that (1) whether defendant was "arrested" at the time certain evidence was seized from defendant's person was immaterial because defendant's detention was reasonable under the Fourth Amendment, which did not require probable cause before prison officials were entitled to detain defendant within the confines of the prison, and did not violate N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-401; (2) the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to declare a mistrial after ruling certain evidence inadmissible that had already been put before the jury; and (3) despite evidence that supported defendant's theory that the killing was done in the heat of passion, the evidence supported the charge of first degree felony murder based on defendant's alleged attempted rape of the victim.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for first degree murder. The court reinstated defendant's life sentence.

 

279 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Utilities Com. v. Nantahala Power & Light Co.


No. 227A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


313 N.C. 614; 332 S.E.2d 397; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1705


April 12, 1984, Heard in the Supreme Court  
July 3, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by respondents pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-30(3) from the decision of the Court of Appeals, reported at 65 N.C. App. 198, 309 S.E. 2d 473 (1983), affirming the order of the North Carolina Utilities Commission entered 2 September 1981, Docket No. E-13, Sub 29 (Remanded) reducing retail electric utility rates and requiring a refund by respondents Nantahala Power and Light Company ("Nantahala") and its parent corporation, Aluminum Company of America ("Alcoa") to Nantahala's retail ratepayers for the four-year period of 1977-1981.



DISPOSITION: Affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent power company applied to the North Carolina Utilities Commission (Commission) for a rate increase, which was approved, and which was later reversed by the Court of Appeals (North Carolina). On remand, the Commission reduced retail electric utility rates and required a refund from the power company and its parent corporation to the retail ratepayers for the four-year period. The power company and its parent corporation sought review.


OVERVIEW: The power company and its parent corporation argued that the order was precluded by exclusive federal licensing of interstate hydroelectric power facilities, that it intruded upon the authority vested in the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC), and that it imposed an impermissible burden on interstate commerce. The court affirmed the order. The Commission's order in no way contravened the terms of the parent corporation's federal license to operate hydroelectric plants and the Commission was not preempted from implementing the roll-in methodology for setting the retail rates by the Supremacy Clause or the FERC's exclusive jurisdiction over certain interstate wholesale power transactions and agreements. Utilization of the roll-in did not grant a preference to the power company's North Carolina customers. Application of the roll-in methodology, with its resulting reduction in retail rates and refund obligation, did not impermissibly impair the power company's ability to earn a proper rate of return on its investment. The Commission acted within its regulatory and rate making authority in imposing the obligation upon the parent corporation to pay any portion of the refund.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision upholding the Commission's order reducing the power company's retail rates and requiring refunds from the power company and its parent corporation to the North Carolina retail customers.

 

280 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Tetterton v. Long Mfg. Co.


No. 260PA84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


314 N.C. 44; 332 S.E.2d 67; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1708; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P10,793



July 3, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On discretionary review of the decision of the Court of Appeals, 67 N.C. App. 628, 313 S.E. 2d 250 (1984), affirming summary judgment entered in favor of defendant Long Manufacturing Company, Inc., during the 18 February 1983 civil non-jury session of Pitt County Superior Court.



DISPOSITION: Modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the administratrix of decedent's estate, challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed the summary judgment entered in favor of appellee tobacco harvester manufacturer (manufacturer) in the administratrix's product liability suit against the manufacturer and co-defendant tractor company after her husband was killed while operating a tobacco harvester manufactured by the manufacturer.


OVERVIEW: The dispositive issue on appeal was whether N.C. Gen. Stat. § 1-50(6), the six-year statute of repose for product liability actions, was constitutional. Preliminarily, the court concluded that the record indicated that the constitutional question was properly presented to and considered by the trial court and the appellate court below and was properly before the court on appeal. As to the dispositive issue, the court concluded that the statute was constitutional. The court found unpersuasive the administratrix's argument that the statute violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and N.C. Const. art. I, § 19, as impermissibly distinguishing between sellers and manufacturers. The court found that the statute did not distinguish between manufacturers and retail sellers of products who were protected from liability beyond the six-year period of repose. The court further held that the statute did not violate the "open courts" provision of N.C. Const. art. I, § 18. The court also found that the language "initial purchase for use or consumption" was not unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court as modified.

 

281 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


Delconte v. State


No. 9PA84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


313 N.C. 384; 329 S.E.2d 636; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1553



May 7, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] On defendant's petition for discretionary review of a decision by the Court of Appeals, 65 N.C. App. 262, 308 S.E. 2d 898 (1983), reversing a declaratory judgment for plaintiff entered by Judge F. Gordon Battle in the Harnett County Superior Court.



DISPOSITION: Reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff father sought discretionary review of a decision of the North Carolina Court of Appeals, which reversed a declaratory judgment for the father entered by the trial court in an action instituted by the father against defendant State of North Carolina. The appellate court concluded, inter alia, that the state's compulsory school attendance statutes prohibited home instruction of the father's two children.


OVERVIEW: The trial court granted a declaratory judgment for the father, ruling that home instruction was not prohibited by statutes on compulsory school attendance and, if it were, then the statutes contravened freedoms guaranteed to the father by the state and federal constitutions. The appellate court reversed. On further appeal, the court allowed the father's petition for discretionary review and reversed the appellate court's decision, holding that the father's home instruction of his children met all the standards for qualification as a nonpublic school under N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 115C-556 to - 558, 115C-560. Further, the father's home instruction met the characteristic set out in N.C. Gen. Stat. § 115-555(4) in that the he received no state funding. Thus, the home instruction satisfied the requirements of compulsory school attendance under N.C. Gen. Stat. §§ 115C-548, 115C-556.The court explained that, without a clearer expression of legislative intent, it was not prepared to hold that the statutes prohibited home instruction as a means of complying with the compulsory school attendance law. The court declined to determine whether home instruction could be constitutionally prohibited.


OUTCOME: The court granted discretionary review and reversed the appellate court's decision in favor of the state.

 

282 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


In re Truesdell


No. 429PA83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


313 N.C. 421; 329 S.E.2d 630; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1554



May 7, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by petitioner, Mecklenburg County Department of Social Services, pursuant to G.S. 7A-30(1) from a unanimous decision of the Court of Appeals, 63 N.C. App. 258, 304 S.E. 2d 793 (1983), affirming in part and reversing in part the judgment entered by Griffin, J., during the 30 November 1981 Civil Session of the Mecklenburg County Superior Court, and further remanding the case to the trial court.



DISPOSITION: Modified and affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county department of social services sought review of a decision of the court of appeals (North Carolina), which affirmed in part and reversed in part a judgment of the Mecklenburg County Superior Court. The county sought sterilization of appellee, a mentally retarded woman, on the grounds that the woman would probably not be able to care for children and that sterilization would be in her best interests and those of the public good.


OVERVIEW: The county department of social services petitioned for an order authorizing the sterilization of the mentally retarded woman. The county claimed that the requirements of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 35-43 were met in the case because the woman suffered from a physical, mental, or nervous disease or deficiency not likely to materially improve, and she would probably be unable to care for a child or children or she would be likely, unless sterilized, to procreate a child or children who probably would have serious physical, mental, or nervous diseases or deficiencies. The lower court denied the petition because the county did not show by clear, strong, and convincing evidence that the woman was likely to engage in sexual activity. The county sought a de novo hearing on appeal, and the court of appeals affirmed the decision of the trial court. The county sought further review. On review, the court found that the lower court did not err in its construction of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 35-43 or in the further requirements of proof that it imposed upon the county.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the lower court denying the order authorizing sterilization sought by the county. The court modified the decision due to insufficient evidence to prove that the mentally retarded woman would be in imminent danger for her life, if a hysterectomy were not performed, and inadequate findings regarding the least drastic means to prevent conception.

 

283 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Peek


No. 117A84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


313 N.C. 266; 328 S.E.2d 249; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1531



April 2, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from Downs, J., at the 16 January 1984 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Mecklenburg County. Defendant was convicted of first-degree rape and sentenced to life imprisonment. He appeals as a matter of right pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-27(a) (1981).

The State's evidence at trial tended to show that the prosecuting witness, Mary Black, spent the evening of 23 April 1983 with her boyfriend in her apartment. She had sexual intercourse with her boyfriend in the apartment prior to 10:00 p.m. when he left for work. As a result of taking pain medication, Ms. Black fell asleep on a sofa in her apartment soon after her boyfriend left. She was awakened by a knock on her front door. She went to answer the door and recognized defendant James Walter Peek standing outside. Ms. Black had known defendant since 1981 when he worked on an interior construction project in the office where she was employed. She and defendant had gone to lunch together a number of times and defendant had visited Ms. Black in her apartment on several occasions. On one such occasion defendant had made sexual advances toward her. Ms. Black testified that she protested and struggled with [***2] him, but that she finally submitted, and had sexual intercourse with him.

On the night of 23 April 1983 after Ms. Black admitted defendant to her apartment, he returned to his car to turn off the car's motor and to retrieve his gun, telling Ms. Black he did not want his gun to be stolen. Defendant reentered the apartment, closed and locked Ms. Black's front door and sat down with her on the sofa. Defendant's gun was in his pocket at that time, but Ms. Black testified that she was not initially frightened by it. Defendant began making sexual advances toward Ms. Black, and she asked him to leave. Assuring her that he would not hurt her, defendant removed a bullet from his gun and gave it to her. Ms. Black and defendant began to struggle on the sofa, and she scratched defendant. When defendant looked in a mirror above the sofa to see the scratch, he told Ms. Black the scratch burned and that he was going to hurt her. At that time defendant had the gun in his hand, and Ms. Black testified that she was afraid of it. Ms. Black threatened to call the police, but defendant told her he would have done what he wanted to do by the time the police arrived. After another struggle Ms.  [***3] Black submitted against her will to vaginal intercourse with defendant. Defendant also attempted to have anal intercourse with her. Ms. Black testified that during the sexual acts, she thought the gun was on the sofa beside her head.

Ms. Black called the police after defendant left her apartment. She was taken to a hospital where a rape kit was prepared. The results of the rape kit revealed that semen was present in both vaginal and rectal smears taken from Ms. Black. Both Ms. Black and her boyfriend denied having engaged in anal intercourse on the evening of 23 April.

Defendant's evidence tended to show that he and Ms. Black engaged in consensual sexual intercourse on the night in question. Defendant testified that Ms. Black neither scratched him nor threatened to call the police. He stated that although he had a gun on his person when he first went to Ms. Black's door, he returned the gun to his car when he turned off the car's motor. Defendant also testified that he and Ms. Black had been lovers for a time and that he had proposed to marry her. He testified that while he worked in the building where Ms. Black was employed, they had lunch together nearly every day and [***4] that he had introduced her to his co-workers as his "lady."

One of defendant's former co-workers testified that he had frequently seen defendant and Ms. Black go to lunch together and that he had observed them holding hands. Another co-worker testified that Ms. Black and defendant appeared to be "going with each other," and that defendant had mentioned spending the night with Ms. Black. Several witnesses stated their opinions about defendant's character.

The jury found defendant guilty of first-degree rape. Although the trial judge eventually sentenced defendant to the mandatory sentence of life imprisonment, he postponed sentencing defendant for one month to investigate alternatives to sentencing. He also conducted a sentencing hearing during which he found five factors in mitigation and none in aggravation cognizable under the Fair Sentencing Act. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-1340.1-1340.7 (1983).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of his conviction for first-degree rape and the sentence of life in prison by the Criminal Session of Mecklenburg County Superior Court (North Carolina). At the sentencing hearing, the trial court found five factors in mitigation and none in aggravation that were cognizable under the North Carolina Fair Sentencing Act, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-1340.1 to 1340.7 (1983).


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant claimed that the trial court prejudicially erred when giving jury instructions after its foreman said that the jury was having trouble reaching a unanimous verdict and in not informing the jury that character evidence could be considered as substantive evidence and as evidence relating to credibility. Defendant argued that a life sentence for rape was constitutionally disproportionate and cruel and unusual punishment. The court held that: (1) because the trial court merely asked the jury to continue to deliberate without an element of coercion, there was no violation of N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-1235; (2) defendant's character evidence did not rise to the level of competent evidence because it did not relate to defendant's general reputation, only how each witness perceived defendant; (3) a trial court is not required to instruct on character evidence even where such evidence was competent; and (4) in view of the seriousness of the offense and the court's obligation to grant substantial deference to the legislature's authority to determine the types and limits of punishments, defendant's sentence was not unconstitutionally excessive, gross, or disproportionate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

284 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Kornegay


No. 500PA84


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


313 N.C. 1; 326 S.E.2d 881; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1511



February 27, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from Martin, J., at the 3 October 1983 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Wayne County.

The grand jury of Wayne County returned a bill of indictment charging defendant, a practicing attorney in Wayne County, with twenty-nine separate counts in the nature of embezzlement or false pretense. The trial court, however, submitted only three counts to the jury: count XVII: Embezzlement of $ 14,500 on or about 13 April 1982 of monies of a client, Carolyn Stallings (individually and as guardian ad litem for John J. Stallings, incompetent) [a violation of G.S. 14-90]; count XXII: Obtaining $ 21,000 from Mrs. Estelle Sutton on or about 29 April 1982 by means of a false pretense [a violation of G.S. 14-100]; count XXV: Malfeasance as a corporate officer by the embezzlement of $ 6,000 on 27 April 1982 of monies belonging to Kornegay, Rice and Edwards, P.A. [a violation of G.S. 14-254].

The State offered evidence tending to show that in 1979 Mrs. Estelle Sutton was involved in an automobile accident in Sampson County in which she was seriously injured. Mr. Seals, the occupant of the other car involved in the accident, died as a result of injuries received in [***2] the collision. While she was still in the hospital, Mrs. Sutton, a 72-year-old widow, sent for Mr. Kornegay to talk to him about representing her in the criminal matters pending against her in which she was charged with the death by motor vehicle and failure to yield the right of way. After consulting with Mrs. Sutton defendant Kornegay advised her that he would charge her $ 3,500 for this appearance in criminal court and at that time obtained an authorization from her to investigate her financial condition. After making this investigation, he thereafter told Mrs. Sutton that his fee would be $ 5,500. Mrs. Sutton attended the trial on the day that she was discharged from the hospital. The court dismissed the charge of death by motor vehicle and a satisfactory plea bargain on the charge of failure to yield the right of way was arranged. On the day of the trial Mrs. Sutton paid defendant his fee of $ 5,500.

During their trip home, Mr. Kornegay advised her that she would probably be sued in a civil action. Several months later she received the summons and complaint in the civil action and carried them to Mr. Kornegay's office. At trial her insurance company, which had a liability [***3] of only $ 25,000, retained Mr. I. Edward Johnson of Raleigh, North Carolina. Defendant Kornegay was retained by Mrs. Sutton to represent her for liability in excess of coverage. Mrs. Sutton did not attend the civil trial because of illness and was advised by defendant Kornegay that the jury had returned a verdict against her in excess of $ 200,000 and that he had given notice of appeal. At that point, Mrs. Sutton paid Mr. Kornegay $ 10,000 for his representation in the civil action.

After some months, Mr. Kornegay obtained a settlement in the matter and he told Mrs. Sutton that the agreement was "to pay the Seals' estate $ 125,000." He then instructed her to bring him two checks: one in the amount of $ 125,000 in settlement of the Seals suit and the other in the amount of $ 6,000 to finish paying his legal fee. On 27 April 1982 Mrs. Sutton delivered the checks to a secretary in Mr. Kornegay's office. Several weeks later she called Mr. Kornegay and asked for something to show that the case was settled. She received a letter dated 1 June 1982 from Mr. Kornegay which in part read: "Pursuant to our telephone conversation, I am writing you this letter to tell you that your case has [***4] been settled. As you know, we paid $ 125,000 to them in full settlement of this matter. As I told you, the judgment against you was recorded in four counties which includes Wayne, Duplin, Johnston and Sampson. It will take some time to get this settled. You do not have anything to worry about." At her request, Mr. Kornegay wrote her a letter in which he stated: "This is to advise you that you have paid my fees in full concerning the wreck." There was no specification as to the exact amount of the legal fees nor as to how these fees were determined.

In October 1982 Mrs. Sutton was contacted by the S.B.I. and at that time she learned that defendant Kornegay had retained $ 21,000 from the $ 125,000 check which she had delivered to him for settlement of the judgments against her in favor of the Seals estate. She testified that she had never authorized defendant Kornegay to take any money out of the $ 125,000 check for himself or his law firm.

In January 1982 the law firm of Kornegay, Rice and Edwards, P.A. opened an office in Kenansville, North Carolina where Mrs. Diane Grubbs was employed as secretary, bookkeeper and receptionist. That office kept two bank accounts in the Bank [***5] of North Carolina, N.A., Kenansville. One account was a firm trust account and the other was the firm's operating account. The first money received by Mrs. Grubbs was a $ 5,000 check from State Farm Insurance Company payable to Carolyn Stallings, and she thereafter received a $ 25,000 check payable to Carolyn Stallings. Mrs. Stallings endorsed both checks and Mrs. Grubbs deposited them in the firm's trust account in Kenansville. On 8 March 1982, upon Mr. Kornegay's instructions, she wrote checks on the firm's trust account as follows: Carolyn T. Stallings -- $ 3,000.00; T. LaFontine Odom -- expenses $ 469.48; Bernard I. Scherer -- attorney's fee $ 3,000.00; T. LaFontine Odom -- attorney's fee $ 4,200.00 and George R. Kornegay -- attorney's fee $ 3,000.00. Messrs. Odom and Scherer were attorneys of Charlotte, North Carolina who had associated defendant Kornegay in the trial and settlement of claims which grew out of a personal injury Mrs. Stallings' husband had suffered when struck by an automobile operated by Bruce Blanton, Jr.

Several months later Mrs. Grubbs noted that Mr. Kornegay had written a check in the amount of $ 14,525 to one Ray Amon from the trust account which then [***6] contained only money belonging to Carolyn Stallings. In October 1982 police officers came to the office and obtained records from Mrs. Grubbs, including the trust account cards. Several weeks thereafter defendant Kornegay gave her cash to put in the trust account and she thereafter prepared a check in the amount of $ 16,280.25 payable to Attorney Odom of Charlotte, North Carolina. There was also evidence that at about this time defendant had borrowed $ 50,000 from Mr. E. J. Pope, Jr. who received as security stock in the Mount Olive Nursing Home.

The State also presented testimony through Mr. Joseph Marion, an attorney who represented the Seals estate. He testified that on 5 May 1982 he received a check dated 28 April 1982 from defendant Kornegay in the amount of $ 104,000 in full settlement of the claim against Mrs. Sutton. This settlement had been reached "about the last week or ten days of April 1982."

Ray Amon testified that he is a used car dealer in Mount Olive and that he sold certain property to Mr. Kornegay for $ 100,000. Amon stated that he received a down payment in the amount of $ 16,000 which was written on the trust account of the firm of Kornegay, Rice and Edwards,  [***7] P.A. Mr. Kornegay paid him the second installment of $ 14,000 by another check drawn on the firm's trust account. He testified that he knew nothing about Carolyn Stallings or her case and that he received no further payment from defendant Kornegay on the note.

Mrs. Elnora Whetsell, who was a secretary in the Mount Olive office of the firm of Kornegay, Rice and Edwards, P.A., testified that she noticed some unusual transactions in the office and in 1981 began copying records and taking them home. She told no one but her husband what she was doing. She stated that "the reason I took those copies home with me was because he [Kornegay] had been very dishonest and when something dishonest happened then I said well what kind of position can I eventually get in and I took the copies home strictly to protect myself." In 1982, after conferring with Judge Michael Bruce, Attorney Edwards and Attorney Rice, she did copy additional papers but did so without the knowledge of any of these people or of defendant Kornegay. After a search warrant was issued in October, she left the law firm. She testified that defendant Kornegay deposited $ 6,000 belonging to the firm into his personal bank [***8] account. She also corroborated the testimony of the witness Amon to the effect that Kornegay wrote checks on the trust fund to Amon, and at that time there was no money in the trust fund which belonged to Mr. Amon. Checks to Amon were down payments and subsequent payments on a debt against the Ramblewood Corporation in which defendant Kornegay owned stock.

The State offered other evidence from Attorney Rice in the nature of corroboration.

Defendant offered no evidence.

The jury returned verdicts of guilty as charged on all three counts. The trial judge pronounced judgment as follows: count XVII -- Embezzlement, the court sentenced defendant to imprisonment for eighteen months and recommended work release privileges; count XXII -- False Pretense, the court imposed a sentence of imprisonment for a term of thirty months and recommended work release upon condition that defendant make restitution to Estelle Sutton in the amount of $ 21,000; count XXV -- malfeasance by a corporate officer, defendant was sentenced to thirty months imprisonment to begin at the expiration of the sentences imposed in count XVII and XXII. The execution of this sentence was suspended and the defendant was [***9] placed on supervised probation for a period of three years. The trial judge also disbarred defendant from the practice of law and profession as an attorney in the State of North Carolina. Defendant appealed to the North Carolina Court of Appeals and we certified the case for discretionary review ex mero motu prior to a determination by the Court of Appeals pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 7A-31(a) and Rule 15(e)(2).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant attorney sought review of a decision from the Superior Court, Wayne County (North Carolina), which found him guilty of embezzlement, obtaining money from a client by means of false pretense, and malfeasance as a corporate officer by embezzlement.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found guilty of embezzlement, obtaining money from a client by means of false pretense, and malfeasance as a corporate officer by embezzlement. On appeal, the court held that the defendant received a fair trial free of prejudicial error. The copied records used against Defendant were not obtained by an unreasonable search and seizure conducted by the State or its agents. The person who copied the records acted entirely on her own and for the purpose of protecting herself. There was sufficient evidence in the search warrant affidavit to show probable cause to believe that defendant had committed the charged offenses because over a period of years, defendant's law partners and others noticed numerous instances of defendant's improper handling of trust accounts of clients and funds of the professional association. Two separate and distinct offenses were charged in each case and the trial court did not err in waiting until the close of all evidence to require the State to make an election between the offenses of embezzlement and malfeasance of a corporate agent.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant received a fair trial free of prejudicial error, in the lower court's conviction of defendant for embezzlement, obtaining money from a client by means of false pretense, and malfeasance as a corporate officer by embezzlement.

 

285 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Todd


No. 523A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


313 N.C. 110; 326 S.E.2d 249; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1520



February 27, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Defendant was tried before Brannon, J., at the 18 July 1983 Session of Superior Court, Bladen County, on charges of felonious breaking or entering and larceny, and being an habitual offender. After the jury returned verdicts of guilty on the charges of breaking or entering and larceny, the question of whether defendant was an habitual felon was submitted to the jury and answered in the affirmative. Pursuant to N.C.G.S. § 14-7.6 defendant was sentenced as a Class C felon and received a life sentence. From verdicts of guilty and a life sentence imposed thereon, defendant appeals as a matter of right.

Before this Court the defendant raises two evidentiary issues; challenges the sufficiency of the evidence; and contends that his conviction as an habitual offender violated his constitutional rights and was unsupported by the evidence. We find no error.



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of judgments entered upon jury verdicts by the Superior Court of Bladen County (North Carolina), which convicted him of breaking or entering and larceny and imposed a life sentence upon him. After the jury returned verdicts of guilty on the charges, the question of whether defendant was an habitual felon was submitted to the jury and answered in the affirmative.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was tried on charges of felonious breaking or entering and larceny, and being an habitual offender. The jury returned verdicts of guilty on the charges of breaking or entering and larceny, and found defendant to be a habitual felon. Pursuant to N. C. Gen. Stat. § 14-7.6, defendant was sentenced as a Class C felon and received a life sentence. On appeal, the court held: 1) the unsupported testimony of an accomplice was admissible; 2) defendant's Miranda rights were not violated because statements made by the defendant to an officer while in custody did not result from an interrogation; 3) there existed sufficient evidence to support the convictions for breaking or entering and larceny; 4) the habitual offender statute was constitutional; 5) defendant's sentence did not violate the Eighth Amendment or the Fair Sentencing Act, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-1340.1 et seq.; 6) it was not necessary to re-empanel the jury prior to hearing the habitual felon case; and 7) the finding in aggravation that the defendant was a sociopath coupled with the finding that he was a menace to others was proper.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions and sentence entered by the trial court.

 

286 of 1540 DOCUMENTS


State v. Higginbottom


No. 634A83


SUPREME COURT OF NORTH CAROLINA


312 N.C. 760; 324 S.E.2d 834; 1985 N.C. LEXIS 1498



January 30, 1985, Filed


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] Appeal by defendant from Brannon, J., at the 12 September 1983 Criminal Session of Superior Court, Onslow County.

On 26 July 1983 defendant was charged with having committed a first-degree sexual offense upon Cassandra Harsen, a four-year-old child. Defendant entered a plea of not guilty.

The State presented evidence through the testimony of Cassandra Harsen and her mother, Jenny Morrell, which tended to show that Cassandra was four years old at the time of the assault and that she lived with her mother in Jacksonville. In May 1983 Cassandra was left in the care of defendant and his wife, Nina Higginbottom, while Ms. Morrell went on a week's vacation. The two families were well acquainted and had exchanged babysitting services in the past.

Cassandra's testimony tended to show that one night while she was staying with the Higginbottoms, Nina Higginbottom fixed popcorn for the children and put them to bed. Cassandra and the Higginbottoms' three-year-old son, Kenny, shared a bed in Kenny's bedroom. Cassandra went to sleep and was awakened by defendant who entered the bedroom and laid on the bed. Defendant then made the child suck on his penis. Afterwards he asked her [***2] if it felt good and if it tasted good.

Ms. Morrell testified that when she returned from the mountains the following week, Cassandra told her that defendant made her put his "wee-wee" in her mouth.

Defendant's evidence tended to show that on the night in question, defendant, his wife, children, and Cassandra visited a next-door neighbor to celebrate the neighbor's birthday. Mrs. Higginbottom left the birthday party to take the children home and to fix popcorn. Defendant left the party between 10:30 and 11:30 p.m. and returned home. After the children were put in bed, both defendant and Mrs. Higginbottom checked on the children. Mrs. Higginbottom testified that her husband had to go into the children's bedroom to quiet them but that she was nearby while he was in the bedroom. Defendant and his wife returned to the living room where they watched television until late that night. Defendant fell asleep in the den on a love seat and slept there all night. Mrs. Higginbottom slept on a couch in the den. Other evidence presented by defendant tended to suggest that Cassandra told the story about defendant because she was angry at him for not permitting her to spend the night with [***3] some of defendant's friends. A number of witnesses testified that Cassandra behaved normally after the night in question and that defendant had a good reputation in the community.

The jury returned a verdict of guilty of first-degree sexual offense. The trial court sentenced defendant to life imprisonment from which he appealed pursuant to N.C.G.S. 7A-27(a).



DISPOSITION: No error.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed, pursuant to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 7A-27(a), his conviction and life sentence in the Criminal Session of Superior Court for committing a first-degree sexual offense upon a four-year-old child.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with committing a first-degree sexual offense upon a four-year-old child. The jury returned a verdict of guilty and defendant was sentenced to life imprisonment. On review, the court affirmed, finding that defendant received a fair trial free of prejudicial error. The imposition of a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment for first-degree sexual offense was not so disproportionate as to constitute a violation of the Eighth Amendment.
